Manton of New York, Edwin S. Thomas and Carroll C. Hincks of this State, which dismissed a petition brought by William Shore of Hartford.

The government invited respectable business people to enter the liquor business to protect society from the disorganizing influence of bootleggers. Many respectable firms answered the call and invested their time and funds, only to have all branches of the government single them out as victims for taxation raids.

Ventures of the Home Title Insurance Company into fields foreign to its business of lending money on mortgages resulted in losses of about $1,250,000, Henry J. Davenport, president of the company, testified yesterday before George W. Alger, Moreland Act commissioner.

LONDON, May 16. -- Miss Helen Lee Doherty of New York, who is attached to the staff of Minister Ruth Bryan Owen in Copenhagen, was among the eight women of the United States whom Mrs. Robert W. Bingham presented to King George and Queen Mary at the season's second court in Buckingham Palace tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained thirty-four guests at luncheon today in honor of the members of the Belgian mission which arrived today to announce the accession to the throne of King Leopold III.
The city Fusion party's policy of "exclusiveness" in deciding which local district clubs shall organize under the Fusion banner received a severe blow from the Supreme Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Hiroshi Saito, Japanese Ambassador to the United States, in an interview tonight over the network of the National Broadcasting Company, explained Japan's attitude toward Eastern Asia.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 16. -- Princeton retaliated for an early-season defeat by turning back Rutgers in a twilight game tonight, 5 to 2.

For many years Pelham Bay Park was a haven for hundreds and thousands of motorists who sought its cool breezes after a hot and trying day in the city. The poor clerk or laborer piled his wife and children into the little second-hand car and took them up to Pelham for the day.
NEWTON, Mass., May 16. -- Collecting twenty hits off three Boston University pitchers, Harvard recorded an easy 14 to 4 victory over the Pioneers at Nickerson Field today.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Oswald Inauth, former vice president of 1. 7=I. racy Co., has been appointed retail adviser to Iarry O. Iing, NRA Divisional Administrator. ]Ie is on a per diem basis and spends a day or two each week in Washington.

Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, criticized yesterday the passage on Tuesday by the Aldermen of the bill compelling city employes to reside in the city. He said the measure might displace some department heads of exceptional ability.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Senate silver leaders fell in line today with the substance of President Roosevelt's offer to accept legislation declaring it the policy of Congess to favor nationalizing of silver, but leaving to his discretion the manner and time in which this should be done.

The New Deal has done much good, but it is time to call a halt to some of its extreme enactments and to consider a return to greater private initiative, according to statements made yesterday at the opening of the fourteenth annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

HOW wrong one can go by adapting the apparatus of the collegiate course in logic to a contemplation of human beings! Looked at through the mechanism of a false syllogism, Henry James the Elder, father of the novelist and the Harvard pragmatist, offers little of interest. (The syllogistic method of contemplation and dismissal would run like this: Swedenborg is a mass of nebulosities, infinitely boring.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reported yesterday for the first quarter of this year a consolidated net profit of $5,049,276, after expenses, interest, provision for taxes, depreciation, depletion, reserves and other charges.

LONDON, May 16 (AP). -- Stanley Baldwin, Lord President of the Council, today inferentially accused the United States of causing the breakdown a year ago of efforts to impose an embargo on arms shipments to Bolivia and Paraguay, at war in the Chaco.

Two men were strolling along the banks of Portland Brook in Middlesex County, Conn., on a pleasant day last week. Their attention was caught by the sight of a tanned, bareheaded boy casting a fly in the waters of the brook.

ON BOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA IN THE GULF OF GONAIVES, Haiti, May 16. -- Rear Admiral John Halligan, in command of the fleet's air squadrons, became the proud possessor of a large cake given to him last night after he had made his 1,000th consecutive landing without a mishap on the flight deck of the carrier Saratoga.

It is said that a man who had been twelve years a member of the Senate of the United States was asked about the effect of Senatorial oratory. His reply was: "I have heard many "speeches in the Senate that changed "my convictions, but I thank GOD that "I never heard one which changed my vote."

UTICA, May 16. -- Many men between the ages of 45 and 60 die suddenly because they eat too much, said Dr Harrison S. Martland of Newark, chief medical examiner of Essex County N.J., addressing the closing session of the New York State Medical Society convention here today.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Normal wheat exports from the United States of 125,000,000 to 150,000,000 bushels annually in the not distant future were predicted by Secretary Wallace today as likely to result from the administration's tariff adjustment program.

A radio beacon on the Nantucket Lightship broadcasts electric waves which can be seen, as it were, by ships at any point on the horizon with the aid of suitable electric "eyes." The Olympic turns her own electric eye toward the New England coast. At one point of the compass the radio glare is brightest.

Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, told the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks yesterday that the United States eventually might have to adopt a policy of public ownership and operation of the railroads. Meanwhile, he asserted, motor and water transportation should be regulated, like the railroads, by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., May 16 (AP). -- Long prison terms imposed on Ludwig (Dutch) Schmidt and Basil Banghart today were believed to have marked the overthrow of the machine-gun dynasty of Chicago's "Terrible Touhys."

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Counsel for Western Union threatened to appeal to the courts against imposition of a code for the telegraph industry, at an open hearing today before L.H. Peebles, NRA Deputy. At the same time counsel for the Postal attacked the Western Union for its attitude.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 16. -- Fiery Crags, striking bay gelding owned by the Dixiana Farm of Charles T. Fisher of Lexington, Ky., today captured two of the principal prizes as the Atlantic City Horse Show opened.

The biggest shake-up in the Detective Bureau of the Police Department since John F. O'Ryan became commissioner took place yesterday, when fifteen first-grade detectives were demoted and an equal number of second-grade men were promoted to fill their places.

The legal battle between the Columbia Yacht Club and Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, was settled out of court yesterday when counsel for both sides signed a stipulation by which the club will vacate its premises on the bank of the Hudson River by June 17 and remove its clubhouse by July 1.

PARIS, May 16. -- The Bourse recovered its calm today after yesterday's downward flurry. Opening strong, stocks progressed during the first half of the session, but transactions then became scarce and gains gradually were lost until the close, which was virtually at yesterday's levels.

Mrs. Henry March of the North Shore Country Club won the low-gross award in yesterday's one-day tournament sponsored by the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Pomonok Country Club, in Flushing. Although she had three 7s on her card, Mrs. March returned a 91, finishing a stroke ahead of Miss Rosalie Knapp of the Women's National Golf and Country Club.

Moving off strongly from his rivals in the last furlong, Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Okapi yesterday won the forty-first running of the Toboggan Handicap as the Spring meeting at Belmont Park began, with 12,000 persons present.

Sir George and Lady Dolby and H.G. Wells, English author, are among the passengers booked to sail tonight for Cherbourg and Southampton on the White Star liner Olympic. Others leaving on the ship include:

The State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, in a ruling yesterday, legalized the drinking of wines and liquors at bars, beginning Monday. The board ruled that bars for drinking purposes in hotels and restaurants must be located in the dining room.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 16. -- The Princeton third varsity crew defeated Manhattan's varsity shell by four and a half lengths over a mile-and-a-quarter course on Lake Carnegie today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 (AP). -- An appeal for Federal troops to guard the waterfront, so that non-union workers could load and unload thirty-seven ships tied up in Elliott Bay, was made today, as the ranks of striking longshoremen on the Pacific Coast were swelled by several thousands of seamen who walked out in sympathy with the strikers.

BERLIN, May 16. -- The German debt transfer conference entered the home stretch today, but whether it will achieve even the limited objective of a temporary compromise agreement, that is the best any one dares to hope for, is still very much in doubt.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts awarded yesterday a new issue of $4,000,000 of notes, due Oct. 25, 1934, to the First Boston Corporation. The high bid on a 0.21 per cent basis, plus a premium of $21, topped the second highest bid by a margin of but $14.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday the withdrawal from earmark of $1,750,000 gold and the shipment of the same amount to England. This export of gold to England was the first since January, when shipments of $1,261,000, valued at the old rate of $20.67 an ounce, were reported by the local Reserve Bank.

LONDON, May 16. -- A report from Geneva this afternoon that British, French, United States and Italian delegation chiefs had agreed that the disarmament conference should be adjourned sine die was said by the British Foreign Office to be absolutely groundless.

Governor LEHMAN cannot have found it easy to make up his mind whether to approve or veto the Quinn-Robinson Parole Bill. It was supported by some of the most distinguished penologists in the State, led by his own Commissioner of Correction. The Lewisohn Commission and the Prison Association actively sought its passage.

MOSCOW, May 16. -- Charges that many executives and technicians in the coal fields are serving undeserved sentences of forced labor -- that is, they are forbidden to leave their posts -- because of bureaucratic methods and misplaced zeal in the courts were made today in the newspaper.

Influenced by a recovery in wheat, the silver situation and lack of selling pressure in cotton-producing sections, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved 6 to 10 points yesterday and closed at the top.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

A plea for the support of education to prevent a recurrence of conditions of social and economic unrest was made yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, at a luncheon of the Kiwanis Club in the Hotel McAlpin.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 16. -- A wild pitch by Coultas of Wesleyan in the tenth inning decided a pitchers' battle today, the Army winning by 4 to 3. The Cadets had two runners on at the time.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- Senator Reed won the Republican Senatorial nomination over Governor Pinchot by a plurality which tonight exceeded 100,000.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The Senate as a whole ultimately will settle the dispute over which shall administer the Stock Exchange Bill, the Federal Trade Commission, as asked by President Roosevelt, or a specially created agency proposed by the Senate.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- Latest methods of studying the life processes in cells and the makeup of distant stars were described at the annual Medal Day meeting of the Franklin Institute this afternoon. The speakers were the two recipients of the Franklin Medal, the highest honor the institute can bestow.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The Federal Trade Commission, beginning July 1, will pay close attention to the advertising done over the radio. Any action necessary, the commission said, would be taken under Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, which gives it jurisdiction over unfair methods of competition in interstate commerce.

GENEVA, May 16. -- Anonymous but serious manoeuvring to end the disarmament conference when it resumes here May 29 developed today in the League Council corridors, with the apparent sympathy of the American, British, French and Italian delegations.

WASHIGTON, May 16. -- Fear of entangling alliances and disquiet over the political future in Europe underlay arguments presented today to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee against adherence to the Permanent Court of International Justice.

In apparent contradiction to the view of the American Iron and Steel Institute, which estimated the operating rate for the steel industry at the beginning of the week at 56.6 per cent of capacity, The Iron Age finds from its own inquiries that production is 4.4 points higher, or at the rate of 61 per cent.

TOKYO, May 16. -- In addressing a meeting today of the Minseito (chief minority party), Baron Reijiro Wakatsuki, former Premier, who was Japan's chief delegate to the London Naval Conference, declared renewal of competitive naval building would put Japan in serious financial straits.

The last of the series of city garden tours in aid of the Anne Brown Alumnae Nursery School took place yesterday when throngs visited five private gardens in the heart of Manhattan. The gardens exhibited included enclosures at the rear of city residences and those on terraces of penthouses.
In these days of inflationist scheming it might be well to ponder the moral words of that consistent fighter for honesty, William Cobbett. His fierce eloquence has its particular interest now:

ALBANY, May 16. -- The proposed sale of loose milk in New York City under strict health regulations and the question of whether there is to be an immediate increase in milk prices for consumers and producers will be discussed within a few days by the members of the State Milk Advisory Committee.
Max Martin and Herman Hickman, rivals in the main wrestling match to a finish at the St. Nicholas Arena last night, both were counted out after a head-on collision.

LAHINCH, Irish Free State, May 16. -- A suggestion that examination of the monoplane Leonardo da Vinci, in which Captain George Pond and Lieutenant Cesare Sabelli flew from New York to Ireland might reveal that the machine had been tampered with before the flight started was made by Captain Pond in a special interview today.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 16. -- Recent charges that Argentina, Brazil and Chile were deriving substantial trade benefits as a result of the Chaco war have brought vigorous denials on behalf of Chile.

E.D. Bogoljubow, challenger for the world's chess championship, missed another splendid opportunity to gain a victory over Dr. A1exandre Alekhine in the twelfth game of their match, the full score of which has been received here. The game was played at Stuttgart, Germany.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field of Lloyds Neck and Mrs. Harrison Williams of Bayville won the blue ribbons today in the two large decorative classes in the final showing in the twenty-eighth annual tulip show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society at the Pratt Oval on the Pratt estate.

Martin Conboy, United States Attorney, who was shocked when he read James Joyce's "Ulysses," sought yesterday by reading passages of the book to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals to show just why he considered it to be a "filthy, obscene book."

Fordham unlimbered its long-range artillery yesterday to consummate the downfall of the City College nine, 4 to 2, on the Ram diamond. Maroon bats rifled out a pair of doubles and a triple to the outer reaches of the field, and these extra-base blows accounted in some way or another for all the Fordham runs.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 16. -- William S. Meany Jr. of Tamarack won low gross prize in the Westchester County Golf Association's first one-day handicap tourney of the season that was held at the Grassy Sprain Golf Club today.

Walter B. Pitkin, whose survey of middle age, "Life Begins at Forty," has sold about 127,000 copies and is still selling at the rate of about 1,000 copies a week, will have a two-volume book to be called "A Plan for Youth," ready for publication on June 30 by Simon Schuster.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- Arthur W. Cutten was described today as generally found on the bullish side of the grain market. Ross Kidston, partner in the grain firm of James Kidston Co., testified that the operator was bullish during a twenty-five-year period "ninety-nine times out of a hundred," and similar testimony was given by Arthur F. Lindley, a partner in Clement, Curtis Co.

Devereux Milburn, for years the leading figure in American polo, is coming back to an active part in the game, according to the announcement made yesterday F. S. von Stade, vice chairman for the East of the United States Polo Association.
All utility reports are consolidated returns, including subsidiaries, unless otherwise specified.

NEWARK, N.J., May 16. -- The Army Air Corps ended its two months of flying the mails tonight when the last army mall plane landed at Newark Airport at 7:55 P.M. Lieutenant J.L. Kelly was at the controls. In the observation plane O-1-G he had taken off from Jacksonville, Fla., at 10 A.M., stopping at Savannah, Charleston, Florence, Fort Bragg, Richmond, Washington, Baltimore and Camden.

Ray Napolitano, 145, Brownsville, atoned for a previous setback by knocking out Murray Brandt, 142 1/2, Williamsburg, in the fourth round of the scheduled ten-round feature last night at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn. After opening a cut over Brandt's left eye in the third round, the Brownsville welterweight dropped his rival for the full count with a right to the abdomen followed by a left to the jaw in 40 seconds of the fourth.
TORONTO, May 16 (AP). -- Toronto swept the four-game series with Syracuse by taking today's doubleheader, 6 to 3 and 5 to 2.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Convinced by Mayor LaGuardia that the New York City budget was at last properly balanced, Secretary Ickes announced today the allocation of $37,558,500 from public works funds for completion of seven projects delayed for months because the city could not qualify for the huge loans and grants.

FORT SHERMAN, C.Z., May 16. -- Louis Waldman, New York lawyer, indicated the line of the defense in the opening of the retrial of Corporal Robert Osman on a charge of violation of the Espionage Act today by Placing every member of the court martial on record regarding the elimination of the communistic angle developed in the first trial.

Possibly the most encouraging aspect of yesterday's market, from the viewpoint of traders with long commitments, was that selling tended to dry up as stocks reacted. There was no acute weakness at any time, but two or three times there were flurries of selling.
Seeking to end confusion over whether a Controller must be elected this November, the Citizens Union filed a taxpayer's action in Supreme Court yesterday asking for a speedy judicial determination.

Alderman Joseph V. Sangenito, 33 years old, of 207 West 111th Street, was arrested yesterday on a charge of disorderly conduct. The charge was later withdrawn, but in the meantime Mr. Sangenito, who is one of the representatives of the Fusion party at the City Hall, spent several hours in a cell at the West 100th Street police station.

RYE, N.Y., May 16. -- The visit of Lafayette to this village during Colonial times, when he stayed at the local inn and shook hands with most of the Rye villagers, was recalled today by Raphael Petrizzi, a Rye high school student, at ceremonies at which the French Government bestowed its Lafayette medal on the local high school in recognition of its methods of teaching the French language.

BERLIN, May 16 (London Times dispatch). -- Philip Pembroke Stephens, Berlin correspondent of The London Daily Express, with his wife and her cousin, D.P. Reynolds, were arrested while motoring near Magdeburg last night, only to be released on parole tonight after the strongest representations from official quarters.

Suspensions for six months each have been imposed upon Gavin Muir and Douglas Gilmore by the Actors Equity Association on charges brought against the two players by Wee Leventhal. This action was taken by the Equity Council at its regular weekly meeting on Tuesday, and both actors were officially notified yesterday.

Walter L. Johnson, former vice president of the New York Stock Exchange and former president of the New York Cotton Exchange, was elected yesterday chairman of the Stock Exchange committee on publicity. He succeeds James C. Auchincloss, who was not re-elected a governor.

Bonds of all classifications were steady on the Stock Exchange yesterday in quiet trading. Speculative railroad bonds in the domestic list showed the best gains on the day, a fairly representative group mounting a point or more. The industrials and utilities were a shade lower on the average.

Strong support of the protesting pastors in Germany and a clear intimation that the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America cannot permanently recognize the present German Evangelical Church administration unless it makes radical changes in policy is expressed in a letter sent by the Rev. Dr. Albert W. Beaven of Rochester, N.Y., president of the council, to the Right Rev. Lord Bishop of Chichester, England.

THAMESVILLE, Ont., May 16 (AP). -- Enthusiastic over a "very lovely" trip, marred only by the loss of an angel food cake and a slight accident on landing, Mrs. Jeanette Piccard completed her first balloon flight here today.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 16. -- Walter Johnson and his speedball were seen in action again today when the Cleveland Indians defeated Cornell, 11 to 4, in an exhibition game.

PORTHCAWL, Wales, May 16. -- Miss Pare Barton, l7-year-old London girl who left school only last month, will meet Mrs. A.M. Holm, the former Scottish champion, in the final round of the British women's open golf championship tomorrow.

ALBANY, May 16. -- Governor Lehman vetoed the Porter bill to permit construction of a memorial tower atop Whiteface Mountain in the Adirondacks. The Governor declared the tower would mar the natural beauty of the summit.
MANILA, P.I., Thursday, May 17 (AP). The Far Easterr Olympic Games were rained out today, causing postponement of the day's events until tomorrow and extension of the program throuhg Sunday.

TUCSON, Ariz., May 16 (AP). -- Further study of the desert dungeon in which June Robles was kept chained for nineteen days by her kidnappers was made today by the authorities in the hope of finding clues to their identity.

BUENOS AIRES, May 16. -- The Mayor and other municipal authorities fled in panic from Frias, a town of 8,000 inhabitants in the province of Santiago del Estereo, leaving the citizens to their fate, following an outbreak of bubonic plague, which has caused twelve deaths in the past few days.

Bunching hits with misplays in the fifth and the eighth innings, the Manhattan College baseball team defeated the Long Island University nine, $ to 3, in a loosely played contest at Manhattan Field yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Home work is to be permitted in some cases despite code prohibitions, according to an executive order signed by President Roosevelt and made public today.

On Tuesday the Council of the League of Nations took up the question of the Saar Valley. Under the Versailles Treaty it is to be decided by a popular election next year whether the territory is to be restored to Germany or placed under French jurisdiction. Until HITLER came to power, it was generally expected that the inhabitants of the Saar would vote to resume German citizenship.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 16. -- The former Australian sprint champion Winooka failed at Churchill Downs today in his initial 1934 start when the Brookwood Farm's Ebony Lady, an 18-to-1 shot, nosed him out in a six-furlong dash.

James H. Cruikshank, operator, bought from Mary U. Hoffman the six-story apartment house at 55 West 109th Street. The house is on a plot 47.8 by 100 feet, between Manhattan and Columbus Avenues, and was sold through Potter, Hamilton Co.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., May 16. -- Closely following the May Day demonstration of goodwill on the part of 19,000 Endicott-Johnson workers, the management granted today a three-day vacation with full pay to all employes beginning Memorial Day.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- A sharp increase in urban relief needs since the termination of the Civil Works program was shown in reports from 140 cities and urban counties made public today by Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- President Roosevelt came out today in favor of administration by the Federal Trade Commission of Stock Exchanges as provided in the House's regulation bill instead of by an independent agency as set up in the Senate measure.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 16. -- En route to Detroit the Yankees stopped here today and lost an exhibition game to the Rochester Red Wings of the Cardinal farm system. The score was 9 to 8 in a game played as the first part of a double-header before 8,000 fans.

Three Awards Were Created This Year -- One Commemorates General Balbo's Flight. Winners of eight fellowships and scholarships for the study of Italian were announced yesterday by Professor Giuseppe Prezzolini, director of the Casa Italians of Columbia University. Three of the fellowships, one commemorating the flight of General Balbo, were created this year.

The tide has been running slightly more than 2 to 1 in favor of approval of the Roosevelt administration in the first returns to be tabulated in The Literary Digest's new nation-wide poll, it was announced last night by Graham McNamee in a broadcast over an NBC network of stations as far West as Omaha and Kansas City.
LONDON, May 16. -- Edward Leslie Burgin, Parliamentary Secretary of the Board of Trade, told the American Chamber of Commerce yesterday that Great Britain was the best customer of the United States.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 16. -- Extra-base hits helped St. John's University of Brooklyn to defeat the Upsala College nine today, 5 to 2.

LONDON, May 16. -- Commander Oliver. Locker-Lampson, Conservative, failed today in an attempt to introduce in the House of Commons a bill to prohibit the wearing of uniforms for political purposes. The proposed measure was aimed at Sir Oswald Mosley's Black Shirts.
ALBANY, May 16. -- The Ives bill to require teachers to take an oath to support the Constitutions of both the nation and the State was vetoed by Governor Lehman today.

Most of the commodities on futures markets here showed improvement yesterday with the exception of rubber and silk, where declines appeared in moderate trading. The gains in other staples were small. On the cash markets wheat, corn, rye, flour and cotton were higher, while declines occurred in oats, coffee, cocoa, lard, printcloth and rubber.

Westchester's three-day music festival will begin tonight at the County Centre in White Plains and will continue through Saturday night. Sandor Harmati is the conductor, and tonight's program will be devoted to Bach and Wagner, including the third act of "Die Meistersinger."

The Anaconda Copper Mining Company reported yesterday for the three months ended on March 31 a consolidated net income of $1,636,468 after operating expenses, taxes and depreciation, but before depletion. This is equal to approximately 19 cents a share on the 8,672,670 common shares of $50 par value outstanding.

The Fusion administration was accused of preparing to use the $25,000,000 Federal grant for slum clearance as a "political football" for the Fall elections last night at a stormy meeting of the East Side Chamber of Commerce, at 130 Bowery.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- A complete revision of the Moving Picture Code and transfer of the amusement administration to a new divisional administrator, will be demanded in the Darrow report, moving picture circles were informed unofficially here today.

Debutantes of recent seasons will act as manikins in the fashion showing to be a feature of the luncheon hour today for the formal opening of the Park Lane Gardens. The entertainment will aid the child placing and adoption committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

The New York School of Applied Design for Women, 160-162 Lexington Avenue, has awarded prizes in its forty-second annual exhibition now on view at the school. Winners were selected by a Jury of representatives of trades and industries. The principal prizes were:

In view of the demoralization of the great Pennsylvania Republican machines in 1932, Senator REED'S majority in Tuesday's primary is unexpectedly large. Governor PINCHOT has acquired many friends in various camps. As a rich man in politics his heart beats for the poor, and his wrath is hot against all machines but his own.

Subpoenas calling for their appearance before the House committee investigating Nazi and other foreign propaganda in the United States were served here yesterday on several persons. The committee will conduct hearings today, tomorrow and Saturday in the Bar Association Building at 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 16. -- A plea that Americans view other countries with tolerance was made by Dr. George E. Vincent of Greenwich, former head of the Rockefeller Foundation, in an address on the subject "As Others See Us," before the annual convention of the State Federation of Women's Clubs at its opening session in the First Presbyterian Church this afternoon.
Roberto Escobar, the Consul General of Colombia in New York, and his mother, Senora Roberto Escobar, gave a dinner last night at the New Weston. Among their guests were:

Reports for 1933 filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission disclose changes and reapportionments in salaries paid by the Reading Company and the Central Railroad of New Jersey following the unification of their control early in the year.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Convinced through conferences with House leaders that early adjournment of Congress was desirable, President Roosevelt further trimmed his "must" calendar today to measures which he was assured could be disposed of by June 9.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., May 16. -- Secretary of War George A. Dern visited this afternoon the proposed site for a State park at Sandy Hook after a tour of inspection of the New York harbor defenses at Fort Hancock. The visit was made at the request of the Sandy Hook State Park Commission and marked the first time since the establishment of this encampment after the Revolutionary War that a Secretary of War journeyed here.

BERLIN, May 16. -- The Boerse continued in an optimistic mood today, the turnover being so reduced there were not enough offerings to affect the buoyant tendency of bidding. Price changes held within moderate limits and no real market significance attached to any movements.
WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The Federal Trade Commission today made public a list of ten new securities registration statements amounting to more than $10,600,000.
Housing and plots in various communities changed hands in the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

Most Canadians have a great admiration for and confidence in your President. Like Americans, we have believed that he would raise commodity prices, by one means or another -- as he said he would. After this statement we all believed that the depression had turned the corner and business and times were on the upgrade.

The Downtown Gallery, 113 West Thirteenth Street, has opened its annual exhibition of works of art priced uniformly at $100. Thirty- two artists are represented, one example by each being displayed. Several of them, however, have been kept busy supplying fresh material to replace that sold.

The Board of Aldermen has solemnly decreed that no person not a resident of this city shall be eligible for its service, and has imposed sundry other qualifications equally obnoxious and discriminatory. The next step is for the Mayor to veto the ordinance. This he is confidently expected to do, since its palpable intent is to ostracize some of his most valuable appointees.

Business in money was featured by the lending of a small amount of one-year funds at 1 per cent. So far as the record goes this is the lowest rate for that length of accommodation since the pre-war days. The nearest approach to it was the making of eight-months' loans at 1 per cent a short time ago.

More than 5,000 men will receive work for periods ranging from four to twenty-two months as a result of the granting of $37,558,500 of PWA funds to the city by the Federal government, it was said yesterday.
Five hundred longshoremen who are on strike at the piers of the Clyde-Mallory Steamship Line voted to continue the strike at a mass meeting yesterday afternoon at 167 Eleventh Avenue.
Twenty-eight players, including Ellsworth Vines, William Tilden and Henri Cochet of France, were drawn yesterday for the first Eastern professional lawn tennis championship.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- A.V. Dalrymple, special assistant to the Attorney General, asserted today that prominent Republicans "conspired" at a meeting at the Virginia home of Patrick J. Hurley, former Secretary of War, to keep Republicans in government jobs and oust Democrats.

BERLIN, May 16. -- The trial of Erwin Schulze, a house painter, on a charge of throwing a hand grenade into Unter den Linden on March 21, began today before the Summary Court in Berlin, and Germany found herself faced again with a case as strange and mysterious as that of Marinus van der Lubbe and the setting of the Reichstag.

Approximately 2,250,000 NRA dress labels were sold by the Code Authority last week, marking the largest sale of labels since the use of the insignia began last January, it was announced yesterday by Charles L. Elfelt, assistant chairman of the Dress Code Authority.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Steps that the United States may take to cooperate with other powers in bringing about peace in the Chaco between Bolivia and Paraguay promise to be defined in the communication on the manufacture of munitions that President Roosevelt is planning to send to Congress within a few days.

The Annalist Index of Business Activity shows a slight increase of 0.9 point to 79.2 (preliminary) for April from 78.3 for March. The index was 76.8 for February, 73.2 for January and 64.1 for April of last year.
BOSTON, May 17 (AP). -- Manager Frankie Frisch and Virgil Davis pounded home runs when they were needed today to give the Cardinals a 5-3 victory over the Braves in the series' opener.

Peter S. Duryea, executive chairman of the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army, reported yesterday a total of $251,877 in contributions in announcing plans for a "clean-up" meeting to be held Tuesday at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

Advertising and especially newspaper advertisements were urged yesterday by George D. Newton of the Travelers Insurance Company as a weapon in the fight against motor accidents. Speaking at the semi-annual meeting of the Eastern Conference of Motor Vehicle Administrators at the Hotel Lincoln, Mr. Newton suggested that such a campaign be financed by devoting to advertising 1 per cent of the money paid to each State by motor car owners.
Ten properties were offered by auctioneers at foreclosure sales in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday. Nine of the parcels went to plaintiffs and one to an outside bidder. The results follow:

New York City has lost the prophet of her architectural distinction among the cities of the earth. The topless towers of Ilium which furnished a setting for the Homeric epic were but as Bedouin huts by comparison with the structures which his genius lifted high above Manhattan Island.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP). -- From the captain of the United States Davis Cup team for 1934, the confident word went out today that he expects the classic trophy to be returned this year from its wanderings over Europe.

A strong trend characterized trading in virtually all the commodities yesterday, accompanying the rising tendencies in wheat, cotton and the securities markets. The silver market was particularly notable, with futures up about 1 1/2 cent for the day.

Loans on securities to brokers and dealers, as reported by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City in their weekly statement of condition as of Wednesday, published yesterday, fell $5,000,000 to $942,000,000. The decline last week was $27,000,000.

David E. Lilienthal, director and general counsel of the Tennessee Valley Authority, assured the meeting of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks yesterday that investors in public utilities need have no fear of the TVA.

More thought of the possible consequences to other nations should be given in drafting tariff legislation, Thomas W. Lamont, partner in J.P. Morgan Co., said last night at a dinner of the Students International Union at the Hotel Plaza.

A heavy gasoline and electric freight engine of the Pennsylvania Railroad, attached to an empty flat car, ran down tracks from Twelfth Avenue, beneath the Miller elevated highway, yesterday afternoon, and plunged off a loading bridge at the end of the dock between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets, into the Hudson.

A group of officers of the City Company of New York, Inc., security affiliate of the National City Bank, are planning to launch their own investment banking company to carry on the securities business which, under the Banking Act of 1933, must be relinquished by the bank on or before June 16.

V.A. Usievich, chief of the foreign trade division of the Soviet motion picture industry, who is here on a month's visit to establish contacts with producers in the United States, disclosed yesterday that the Soviet plans to produce 100 major films this year.

Major Henry H. Curran states that there are 687,000 World War and Spanish War veterans on the pension rolls. The report of A.D. Hiller, executive assistant to the administrator, dated April 30, states that on March 31 there were on the rolls 124,721 Spanish-American War veterans, and not 222,000, as stated by Major Curran, and 442,269 World War veterans and dependents, and not 465,000, as Major Curran states.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- Disclosure of bear operations carried on by Arthur W. Cutten, involving millions of bushels of grain, and intimations that "venom" and "political strategy" were playing a part in the government action against the market trader, were the high spots of the hearing today in which the government is seeking to have Mr. Cutten barred from future trading on the grain exchanges.
" Murder at the Vanities," based on the Earl Carroll show, will be presented tomorrow at the Rivoli.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- In one of the most critical observations on NRA trade agreements since the Federal Trade Commission's report to Congress on the Steel Code, the Timber Conservation Board reported to Secretary Roper today that in the six months of the Lumber Code "no net progress has been made" toward the primary goal of balancing production with consumption.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Eleven New Yorkers, three of them women, have been indicted by the District of Columbia grand jury in connection with an alleged nationwide liquor ring involving synthetic whisky bearing illicit Federal revenue stamps.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- Unification of all the Eastern railroads, including New England, was suggested today by A.J. County, financial vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

Fifth Avenue looked almost like one of the grand boulevards of Paris yesterday. On the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral were banked great masses of flowers and shrubs. On the terrace of the Public Library was another display and at the north side of Washington Square a third.

The Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company, a subsidiary of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, used misleading and incorrect information in the sale of guaranteed mortgage certificates to the public, according to testimony yesterday before Moreland Commissioner George W. Alger at a hearing in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

Fourteen fraternities at Columbia College have elected officers for the coming year, it was announced yesterday by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes. Dean Hawkes is chairman of the Pamphratria Council, coordinating executive body of which the president of each Greek letter house is a member.

LONDON, May 17. -- The contention that the American monetary experiments have resulted in bringing international financial business to London was advanced by Olaf Hambro, the chairman, at today's meeting of Hambros Bank, Ltd.

BERLIN, May 17. -- Albert Bassermann, 67 years old, the dean of German actors, has just resigned from the German Stage Society and laid down his honorary office because his wife and partner, Elsa Bassermann, a Jewess, was barred from the German stage.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- Martin J. Insull lost his fight today to have a petit jury sit on the legality of the summoning of the grand jury which indicted him. The decision against him, made at a hearing before Judge James F. Fardy in the State Criminal Court, moved his embezzlement case forward, with indications that a date for the trial would soon be set.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 17. -- More than 2,500 persons attended the first of the Westchester Festival's three evening concerts given at the County Centre tonight.
BERLIN, May 17. -- Trading on the Boerse relapsed today from its recent modest buoyancy into new depression. Most active stocks retrograded.

The Olympic was making sixteen knots through the patchy fog last Tuesday morning when Nantucket Lightship was sighted lying across her course less than two ship's lengths ahead, according to testimony heard yesterday by a board of inquiry at the Custom House.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 17. -- Rudy Knepper, former Princeton golfer, led a field of 130-odd players around the Garden City Golf Club course today with a 75, two strokes above par for the tradition-steeped layout.

Domestic corporation bonds pursued their recovery on the Stock Exchange yesterday, rising fractionally to 4 points. United States Government bonds and foreign loans gave ground slightly. Railroad bonds of the second grade and speculative ratings showed the principal gains on the day.
Robert Sinclair has been engaged by Laurence Schwab to direct match as Snatch Can," by Mr. Schwab and Richard MacAuley, when that play goes into production this Summer.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 17. -- Miss Florence L. Sutton of Greenwich was elected president of the Connecticut State Federation of Woman's Clubs at the close of the two days' convention this afternoon, succeeding Mrs. Robert F. Gadd of Hartford.

SHANGHAI, Friday, May 18. -- American insurance companies here are deeply concerned over the arbitrary new fire regulations at Tsinan, the capital of Shantung Province, where Governor Han Fuchu is enforcing a system of heavy penalties on policy holders whose premises are destroyed by fire.

More than 1,000 persons attended the gala luncheon, fashion show and cocktail party which marked the opening of the new Park Lane Gardens at the Park Lane Hotel yesterday. The proceeds of the festivities went to the child placing and adoption committee of the State Charities Aid Association, whose chairman, Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson, headed those who arranged the benefit.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 17. -The annual senior ball will take place at Trinity' College tomorrow evening. The plans, according to [Nathaniel - C. Clark of Boston, chairman of the ball committee, twill include five formal dinners at the houses of Psi Upsilon, Delta Psi, Alpha Delta Phi, Sigma Nu and Delta Phi previous to the ball. The ball will take place under an open-air marquee erected on the campus.

LONDON, May 17. -- Paul Hymans, Belgian Foreign Minister, accompanied by Ambassador de Cartier, had forenoon and afternoon conferences with Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, in London today concerning the probable outcome of the disarmament conference.

Five hundred employes of Stock Exchange firms, who have been studying under the direction of the New York Stock Exchange Educational Institute, attended a dinner last night at the luncheon club of the Exchange. Allen L. Lindley, vice president of the Exchange, presented certificates to the first graduating class of the Member Firm Stock Exchange Institute and prizes to outstanding students.

Historical and literary Americana were sold for $13,712.50 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., in settlement of the estate of the late Mrs. Richard H. Dana of Cambridge, Mass. Much of the property had been in the Dana family since the time of Francis Dana (1743-1811).

DENVER, May 17 (AP). -- The 10-year-old grandson of a former Governor of Tennessee, found here today by detectives who took into custody the boy's father and another man for allegedly kidnapping the youth from a Clarksville (Tenn.) school, said that he had "become reconciled" to living with his father in the West, but was "glad I'm going to go home to mother."

SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 (AP). -- Two violent outbreaks, in one of which six persons were reported hurt and one kidnapped, marked the longshoremen's strike today just after the arrival of Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, to begin conferences designed to end the coast-wide walkout which has tied up shipping in several ports since May 9.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Continued increases during April in employment and payrolls, which usually decline in that month following seasonal expansions in February and March, were shown today by Secretary Perkins.

The reported agreement by which a silver bill would be introduced before the adjournment of Congress stimulated cotton trading yesterday. Prices on the Cotton Exchange improved about a dollar a bale and retained a gain of 15 to 17 points at the close.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 17. -- By Request, towering chestnut gelding, owned and ridden by Fred Wettach Jr. of the Trillora Farm of Shrewsbury, N.J., tonight captured the Marlborough-Blenheim $1,000 Jumper Stake, first major event of the annual Atlantic City horse show.

The Polar Star, the plane to be used by the Lincoln Ellsworth trans-Antarctic Flight Expedition in its second attempt to unveil earth's last great unknown continent, has completed a test flight from Los Angeles to Teterboro Airport, N.J., with a record of fuel consumption which assures a wide margin of safety on the projected flight from a base at Deception Island.

Dominick Bellizzi, Brookmeade Stable rider who was injured last Saturday when he fell from his mount, Psychic Bid, at the Jamaica course, died at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica yesterday morning. He succumbed after a night of watching by members of the family who had begun to hope that he would recover.

OBERAMMERGAU, Germany, May 17. -- The Passion Play's special tercentenary season began today with initial presentations for the benefit of journalists and other invited guests from all parts of the world.

ATHENS, Greece, May 17. -- The International Olympic Committee today received a cable from the American Jewish Congress urging it to undertake an impartial investigation of the treatment of Jews in Germany before proceeding with plans for the international games there in 1936.

The report of the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company and subsidiaries for 1933 shows in the first calendar year of operation gross operating revenues of $22,139,790, and net earnings of $7,875,509, after expenses and general taxes.
PARIS, May 17 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP). -- Funds to put two new administration measures into effect, the Bank-head Compulsory Cotton Control and Jones Cattle Relief Acts, were voted today by the House.

Fairly conclusive evidence was provided yesterday that the event to which thousands of salt-water anglers of the metropolitan area look forward so eagerly each Spring -- the annual weakfish run in Peconic Bay -- is close at hand.

Impostors who misrepresented their needs to the Emergency Home Relief Bureau, thereby receiving funds, food and clothing which should have gone to deserving cases of destitution, have been forced in the last two months to return a total of $25,181 to the bureau, according to Edward Corsi, its director.
PRESTWICK, Scotland, May 17. -- The vanguard of America's Walker Cup team began practice today for the British amateur golf championship, opening here next Monday.

Henry Hazlitt, in his review of James P. Warburg's book, "The Money Muddle," in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Sunday, May 13, states that "Mr. Warburg makes an occasional misleading statement. He seems to believe that symmetalism involves the creation of an actual gold-silver alloy.

GENEVA, May 17. -- Great Britain proposed today that the League of Nations Council resume negotiations for an arms embargo against both Bolivia and Paraguay as "urgently necessary" to end "the senseless loss of life and utterly unjustifiable destruction of the best resources in men and material in these two countries."
UTICA, N.Y., May 17. -- Lumbering of the 100,000-acre Whitney estate, containing some of the last primeval forest of the Adirondacks, began this week.

BABYLON, L.I. May 17. -- The final cut permitting the waters of the main State boat channel to flow into Fire Island Inlet has just been made. It signaled the realization of a program conceived by members of the Long Island State Park Commission seven years ago and started six years ago.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z., May 17 (AP). -- The prosecution scored a point in the espionage retrial of Corporal Ralph Osman of Brooklyn, N.Y., this afternoon when the court overruled objections to introduction of a "dead letter" as evidence against him.

TUCSON, Ariz., May 17. -- Questioning of one suspect in the kidnapping of 6-year-old June Robles was quickly discontinued this afternoon when the mother of the rescued child told Federal operatives that June was re-enacting experiences of her kidnapping and imprisonment for the entertainment of neighborhood children.

A signed editorial in the current issue of the magazine Today by Raymond Moley, former member of the brain trust, warns that the Roosevelt administration "will suffer disastrous reverses "unless it gets better men to operate the structure it has erected."

GENEVA, May 17. -- Hugh R. Wilson, United States observer at the League of Nations Council, promised today to ask for instructions regarding the proposal for a Chaco arms embargo put forward by Captain Anthony Eden of Great Britain.
LONDON, May 17 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Mrs. Elizabeth C. Bosley, owner of the unbeaten thoroughbred Chase Me, declared yesterday at Belmont Park that she still was undecided on sending her color-bearer against C.V. Whitney's Equipoise in the Metropolitan Handicap tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- What is making the Republican politicians happy about the renomination of Senator Reed in Pennsylvania is not a conviction that it means a Republican Congress next year, or a Republican President in 1936. They are happy because they believe the result will help to re-knit party lines in this country.

A vigorous denial that there is an overwhelming opposition to the League of Nations in this country was made yesterday in a statement issued by Clark M. Eichelberger, director of the National League of Nations Association.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday several changes in Stock Exchange partnerships and several transfers of Stock Exchange memberships.

An increase in active play facilities in Central Park was announced yesterday by the Park Department, following recent criticism of the department for failure to make adequate provision in the park for children. Park Commissioner Moses denied, however, that any connection existed between the announcement and the criticism.

Complete plans for the return of the Kent School crew to the Henley regatta this Summer in England, there to defend the Thames Challenge Cup, have been announced by the Rev. F.H. Sill, head master of the school and coach of all the strong eights which have been turned out there.

With $37,558,500 allocated by the Federal PWA for seven local improvements, Budget Director R.E. McGahen estimated yesterday that the new work would give employment directly and indirectly to 7,500 persons. A total of 1,606,000 man-days of work is involved.

LOUIS, May 17 (AP). -- Held scoreless for seven innings by southpaw Fritz Ostermueller, the Browns staged a four-run uprising in the eighth and defeated the Red Sox, 4 to 3, in the series opener today. Manager Rogers Hornsby hit a home run with one man on base.
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- President Roosevelt will send to Congress within ten days a message embodying the most far-reaching program of social and economic reform ever submitted to Congress.

With fresh news from Washington to whet the speculative appetite, the stock and commodity markets advanced sharply yesterday in fairly active trading. In the investment market, domestic corporation bonds moved forward again, but United States Government obligations were easier.

A painting by the Sienese artist Bernardino Fungai (1460-1516) -- "Madonna and Child With Cherubs" -- brought $2,100 last night when offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., in a collection of pictures assembled by the late Anne W. Penfield of Philadelphia.
LONDON, May 17. -- The government has decided on the continuance indefinitely of the tariff on iron and steel, which was due to expire Oct. 24.
BERLIN, May 17. -- Disciples of the Nordic cult from all parts of Northern Europe met today at Bremen to take part in the second annual Nordic "Thing" or diet, called by the president of Hansa House.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 17. -- Max L. Simon, 42 years old, of Passaic, lawyer and newspaper publisher, was found guilty tonight by a jury in Union County Quarter Sessions Court here of causing arson to be committed and of aiding in the arson of The Elizabeth Evening Times, which he owned, Oct. 17, 1931.
BERLIN, May 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of May 15 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

Back among more congenial surroundings and confronted by the no less congenial Cincinnati Reds, the one team they had been able to trounce on their recent disastrous tour through the provinces, the Giants moved safely back into championship stride at the Polo Grounds yesterday as they opened their first home stand against the Western clubs.

Various means for determining distance, as well as direction, during a fog at sea have been available for many years. The submarine signaling apparatus has been extensively used. There are also appliances which will accomplish this result without requiring on the merchant ship any special apparatus other than the radio with which all are equipped.

TULSA, Okla., May 17. -- Secretary Ickes of the Interior Department, in an address to oil men today as Federal Oil Administration, urged their aid to obtain passage at this session of Congress of the production control bill.

DALLAS, Texas, May 17. -- Assets of national banks increased more than a billion dollars in the first two months of 1934, but there was a decline in loans and discounts, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, said here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 17. -- The American system of taxation encourages the fire trap, according to Harold S. Buttenheim, New York, editor of the magazine The American City, who addressed the National Fire Protection Association at its closing session here today.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 16, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,482,000,000, a decrease of $2,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $196,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1933.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, May 17 (AP). -- The Dubuque Telegraph Herald tonight said that the Federal agents working in this vicinity have announced the discovery of the hide-out used by John Dillinger after he shot his way out of a trap at Little Bohemia resort in Northern Wisconsin, and the farmhouse where Edward G. Bremer, St. Paul banker, was held captive for $200,000 ransom by kidnappers.

Some of the proposals regarding sales of munitions of war in peacetime are at present ruled out of general acceptance. But when at Geneva the British Government, supported by six other countries, calls upon all the nations in which war material is manufactured to forbid its sale to either Paraguay or Bolivia, we get something more definite and feasible.

Putting themselves on exhibition before 6,000 home fans for the first time in nearly a month, Casey Stengel's Dodgers yesterday scored a ten-inning triumph over the Pirates at Ebbets Field, 2 to 1. The setback dropped Pittsburgh from first to second place.

BUENOS AIRES, May 17. -- American powers in the neighborhood of the Chaco conflict hold they cannot enforce any embargo on arms against Bolivia and Paraguay. They point to international law and treaties as the reason. They say the only way to keep arms from the belligerents lies in a cessation of exports by all nations.

OBERLIN, Ohio, May 17. -- Immediate passage of anti-war legislation was urged in a letter to President Roosevelt signed by heads of more than 100 colleges. The letter declared another war would be a "terrible disaster for the United States."
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 17 (AP). -- Marvin Duke was too strong for Rochester today and turned back the Red Wings, 1 to 0, to give Newark a clean sweep of the four-game series.

The New York Federation of Music Clubs will hold its annual junior rally in Roerich Hall Saturday afternoon, where winners of the morning's junior contests will receive their rewards and play one of the contest numbers.

With the recovery program now in the administrative stage, it is up to the local code authorities to play a vital role in reinvigorating the NRA -- "now at its lowest ebb," A.D. Whiteside, former division NRA administrator, said yesterday at a luncheon given in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria by the code authorities of this city.

Joseph B. Keenan Assistant United States Attorney General, who has charge of the government's campaign against crime, received word from Washington last night that President Roosevelt will sign the anti-crime bills at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

Almost 3,000 girls danced around Maypoles in Central Park yesterday afternoon at the twenty-seventh annual Park Fete of the girls' branch of the Public Schools Athletic League. The dances and games, directed from a central bandstand in the sheep meadow, with music provided by the George Washington High School Band, have been the same since the fates were started.
ALBANY, May 17. -- The D.T. O'Brien bill, prohibiting insurance companies from making any loans to officers, directors or trustees, was signed today by Governor Lehman.
Deems Taylor, music critic and composer of two operas, said yesterday "operatic tradition" was the main reason for the failure of the opera to be self-supporting in this country.
Housing, business and industrial parcels in various towns were among the New Jersey realty items reported yesterday.

For the quarter ended March 31, the Pennsylvania Railroad Company reported yesterday a net income of $3,808,011, after taxes and other deductions. This is equivalent to 29 cents a share on 13,167,696 shares of $50 par capital stock and contrasts with a net loss of $1,793,854 in the first quarter of 1933.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

At the annual meeting of the Shell Union Oil Corporation yesterday, Ernest Sturm, chairman of the Continental Insurance Company, was elected a director. His election brings the representation of the preferred stock on the board to six members. Viscount Bearsted, chairman of the Shell Transport and Trading Company, Ltd., and J.B.A. Kessler, joint managing director of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company, withdrew as members of the board, reducing the number to seventeen.
GOSPORT, England, May 17 (AP). -- Unless all signs fail, the United States defender of the America's Cup faces a stiffer battle off Newport in September than any of her many predecessors.

So vast an amount of crude theorizing and dogmatism regarding the standard of value has been inflicted on the public by New School economic pundits that the remarks on the subject in its annual report by the World Bank for International Settlements have almost an old-fashioned ring.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended May 12 totaled 341,719,000 barrels, a decrease of 388,000 barrels from the total of 342,107,000 barrels on hand at the end of the preceding week, Secretary Ickes reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- A.T. Foresberg, Minnesota Drought Administrator, said after a conference today with administrators from Montana, the Dakotas and Wisconsin that he would recommend to Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, tomorrow the largest migration of animals ever known.

SYRACUSE, May 17 (AP). -- Dr. Lawrence Geraghty, 29, of 84 Gauthier Avenue, Jersey City, was killed and his wife, Margaret J. Geraghty, 22, was seriously injured early today when their automobile crashed into a pole on a curve near this city.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 17. -- Statistics compiled for the Harvard Alumni Bulletin by its editor, David W. Bailey, from the records of 64,000 living graduates, and published in the current issue, reveal some interesting facts about a "typical" Harvard man.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- While Congress was awaiting President Roosevelt's forthcoming message on silver. Senators who participated in last night's White House conference said that in their final session the President had given assurances that "when conditions were favorable," he would purchase silver to carry out the program agreed upon.

ON BOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, May 17. -- The-United States Fleet completed the last exercise of its cruise today, thus ending one of the most extensive, intricate and arduous series of tactical and strategical problems in its history.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, conferred yesterday at City Hall with Mayor LaGuardia on the strike of coastwise longshoremen. He renewed his promises made to the Mayor at the start of the strike, that picketing would be conducted peaceably unless other tactics were made necessary by employers.

The Academy of Medicine, the Teachers Union and the Civil Service Reform Association joined yesterday in asking Mayor LaGuardia to veto the compulsory city residence bill affecting city employes, passed by the Board of Aldermen last Tuesday.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP). -- Chuck Klein hit his tenth and eleventh home runs of the season and Gabby Hartnett his seventh to help the Cubs score a 10-to-3 triumph over the Phillies today.

Early reports on chain store sales thus far this month show a greater ratio of increase over a year ago than was the case last month, executives said here yesterday. One leading dry goods chain, for example, had a gain of 25 per cent for the first ten days of the month, an increase just about double that noted for the same period in April.

The 225th anniversary of the founding of Trinity School, which began in the tower of Trinity Church in 1709, was celebrated last night with a dinner at the Hotel Astor, which now stands on one of the sites occupied by the school just before it moved to its present building at 139 West Ninety-first Street.

Clinical researches which began in Russia during the war have led to the discovery that the administration of quinine during the early stages of scarlet fever and typhus will prevent the development of these two diseases as it does malaria, it was asserted here yesterday by Professor Georg Zuelzer, noted German physician of the University of Berlin, who arrived on the Manhattan from Germany to demonstrate his work before the American medical profession.

Three plays by Shakespeare, parts of the Bible, patriotic documents and some poems are included with "Very Good, Jeeves," by P.G. Wodehouse; "Diary of a Provincial Lady," by E.M. Delafield, and "As the Earth Turns," by Gladys Hasty Carroll, on the first list of books chosen to be released as "talking books" by the Library of Congress.

Four Federal agents pursuing with drawn pistols two men sought on charges of selling narcotics threw a busy section in the heart of Harlem into an uproar early last night and a bystander was wounded before the fugitives were captured.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Senator Borah challenged President Roosevelt's reciprocity tariff program today as another step away from constitutional democracy. In an address in the Senate, when discussion of the measure formally began, he spoke with a fire and an eloquence that recalled to many of his associates the fight he waged fourteen years ago against the League of Nations covenant.

The recent week-to-week decline in bank clearings continued through the week ended on Wednesday over the country as a whole, but the periodical reports of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., show that a good lead over last year is still being maintained.

Opening a campaign for free speech and free assembly in Jersey City, the American Civil Liberties Union applied yesterday to Vice Chancellor Bigelow in Jersey City Chancery Court for an injunction to restrain Mayor Frank Hague and the municipal police officials from "molesting, harassing or interfering" with meetings of the union or of relief workers organizations in Jersey City.

Believing that nothing succeeds like excess, Rufus King has tossed all of the paraphernalia of the goose-flesh drama into "Invitation to a Murder," which creeped and shuddered at the Masque last evening. The Channings of Southern California are a demoniac family whose fortune was founded on piracy many years ago.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Prices quoted for steel letter files, card sections and desks for government offices have increased so sharply in bids submitted by concerns operating under the NRA that the Treasury Department is hard pressed to obtain equipment for the first half of the new fiscal year without exceeding its appropriation.
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The selection of William P. Kenneally as temporary head of Tammany Hall is displeasing to the friends of President Roosevelt who were behind the efforts to oust John F. Curry.

Mayor LaGuardia said last night that he would confer today or tomorrow with Charles H. Baldwin, State Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, in an effort to work out a distribution system of milk here at lower prices than now obtain.

Mrs. Payne Whitney's defeated Kentucky Derby and Preakness competitor, Spy Hill, scored his most impressive victory so far this year in the featured Burgomaster Purse at Belmont Park yesterday. A head back of the son of Spion Kop at the end of the mile was William Woodward's Faireno.
The Flatbush fan took off his hat, gazed at it, put it back on his head again and remarked:
MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 17. -- B.F. Few won the championship of the Manhattan Club in the annual tournament over the links of the Winged Foot Golf Club today with a score of 84.

President Roosevelt has retained more than 80 per cent of the strength he showed in the 1932 election and has won, in addition, about 41 per cent of the votes cast then for Herbert Hoover, it was indicated yesterday by additional figures in the "New Deal" poll conducted by The Literary Digest.

The intercollegiate polo championship will be played once more in Westchester County, at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club in Purchase. This was announced following the meeting yesterday of the executive committee of the Intercollegiate Polo Association, which also issued the playing dates for the tournament -- June 9 through June 16, inclusive.
CHICAGO, May 17. -- What Henry Ford said to Samuel Insull when the pair met in the latter's hospital room was the topic of table talk today.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Conferees on the Stock Exchange Regulation Bill, meeting for the first time this afternoon, thrust aside temporarily discussion of the chief controversial points, including what agency shall administer the new law.

OTTAWA, May 17. -- Canada's new central bank will not be owned by the Canadian Government, and its governor apparently will be an Englishman. The House of Commons banking committee today voted down liberal motions to have ownership and control of the central bank vested in the Canadian people, and to choose Canadian nationals as its governor and deputy governor, instead of merely British subjects, as provided in the central bank bill.
Federal, State and city officials broke ground yesterday afternoon for the new $37,000,000 vehicular Midtown Hudson Tunnel between West Thirty-ninth Street, Manhattan, and Weehawken, N.J.

Summer shows are opening, now, in swift succession. A group of canvases, new and of considerably earlier date, has been installed for a warm-weather "run" at the Kraushaar Galleries. The roster is about as usual, although Mr. Eraushaar at intervals adds a new artist to his list of regulars.

Declaring Hitler agitation in this country now was as much a matter for government investigation as German propaganda during the World War, Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, a leader in the woman's peace movement, yesterday urged the representatives of all women's organizations to petition President Roosevelt to take immediate action.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 17. -- The opening concert of the Westchester County Music Festival tonight in the County Centre was inaugurated by a Bach chorale sung by an ensemble of fourteen community choral groups. After this the audience listened to a program of Wagner, which included a condensed version, with English text, of the third act of Meistersinger.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., May 17. -- Mrs. H.G. Dow of the Westchester Country Club captured low gross honors in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association over the Scarsdale Golf Club course today. The victor led the field of seventy-five players with a 93.

SAN QUENTIN, Calif., May 17 (AP). -- With the remark that "kidnapping is a lousy racket, it wasn't such a paying proposition as we thought," the three self-confessed kidnappers of William F. Gettle entered San Quentin prison today to begin serving life sentences.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 17. -- A writ of habeas corpus to free him from San Quentin prison was denied to Tom Mooney in Federal Court here today.
Two boys were drowned yesterday in the Hutchinson River in the Bronx and a third was rescued when their canoe overturned in midstream. The bodies were not recovered.

The State drive to collect taxes from delinquent taxpayers, begun here Wednesday, is expected to yield $5,800,000 in additional revenue throughout the State, Tax Commissioner Mark Graves estimated yesterday. Of this total, $2,500,000 is expected from delinquent alcoholic beverage taxpayers, $2,500,000 from uncollected income taxes and $800,000 from sales tax delinquents.

A partial reconstruction of public utility companies in the State of Ohio formerly controlled by the Insull interests is to be effected by the Manufacturers Trust Company through the Utility Service Company, which it controls.

After hearing testimony describing a street brawl, which resulted in the death of Tyler Cook Bronson, retired broker, his brother announced in court yesterday that he did not wish to make a complaint against a 26-year-old Negro taxicab's driver who was accused of striking the fatal blow.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Music sung and played by men and women from the Virginia mountains was the feature of an entertainment following a dinner given by President and Mrs. Roosevelt in honor of Governor and Mrs. Lehman at the White House tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- National banks will be permitted to buy and sell corporate stocks solely for the account of their customers unless Congress passes an amendment to the Glass Banking Act of 1933 specifically prohibiting such practice, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The new silver proposal has excited a variety of questions as to its scope and meaning. Here are some of them, with answers supplied on the basis of information at the Treasury:

GENEVA, May 18. -- Undeterred by Japan's recent warnings, the committee on China of the League of Nations Council examined today the report of Dr. Ludwig Rajchman on his first year's work as the League's technical agent for Chinese reconstruction.

ALBANY, May 17. -- An increase of one cent a quart in the price of bottled milk delivered to the doorstep and sold at stores, with provisions to sell either bottled or loose milk at considerably reduced prices in the poorer sections, today appeared the probable solution to New York City's milk-price problem.

CLEVELAND, May 17 (AP). -- Four runs behind the Senators when they went to bat in the third inning today, the Indians tied the score, took a one-run margin in the fifth and then scored seven runs in the seventh inning to win by a score of 14 to 6.

TOKYO, May 17. -- By proposing abandonment of the ratio principle at the 1935 naval conference, Japan will not be demanding equality with the United States in the sense of the parity the United States claims with Britain, but "defensive equality."
A strike of the "out front" employes of all Radio-Keith-Orpheum and Loew theatres in New York was under way yesterday at the call of the Theatre and Amusement Employes Union, Local 118.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The New Deal emerged from the Pennsylvania primaries with the voters' approval, according to Joseph F. Guffey, Democratic Senatorial nominee, who called on President Roosevelt today.

There was no report of any further lending of one-year money at 1 per cent as was done on Wednesday. On the contrary, the market settled back to the routine requirements of the day. Quotations for all classifications remained unchanged.
PARIS, May 17. -- Dr. Ludwig Rajchman will not return to China to carry on the League of Nations' work of economic rehabilitation, it is reported on good authority here.

LONDON, May 17. -- Trading on the stock markets was fairly active today, outstanding aircraft stocks being particularly strong on reports that the companies had received substantial government orders. Gold mine shares were buoyant on expectations of a further rise in the price of the metal.

Five bookkeepers of the defunct Harriman National Bank and Trust Company were called as witnesses for the government yesterday in Federal Court to tell what they knew about the $1,600,000 false entries posted in depositors' accounts.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., May 17. -- An exceptionally fine team of Long Island golfers carried off the Golf Illustrated Trophy for the second consecutive year by defeating both Westchester and New Jersey in the women's intersectional team matches today.

Admiral Sir Lewis Bayly, retired, of the British Navy; Sir Arthur Newcastle, chairman of the Newcastle Exchange, and J.C. Newman, chairman of the Montreal Harbor Board, are among the passengers arriving today on the Cunarder Aquitania. Others are:

With Nazi swastikas dominating the scene and 750 policemen on hand to prevent disorders or interference, more than 20,000 persons heard speakers denounce "the Jewish boycott" of Germany, and defend Hitler policies last night in the Madison Square Garden.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of directors of the Chase National Bank of the City of New York, was elected president of the State Charities Aid Association yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the association's board of managers at the Bankers Club. Mr. Aldrich succeeds the late George F. CanfieId.

Present and former parishioners of the Rev. Dr. George U. Wenner attended a reception given in his honor last evening in Christ Lutheran Church, 406 East Nineteenth Street, to commemorate his ninetieth birthday. It was also the sixty-seventh anniversary of the church which he founded and which he has served as pastor for sixty-five years.

Barnard School and Brooklyn Poly Prep shared the honors in the annual tennis tournament of the association of private schools of New York City yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, L.I.

DETROIT, May 17 (AP). -- Clotho, with Robbie Robertson, up, established a new track record of 1:104-15 to win the Detroit Inaugural Handicap at six furlongs, featuring the opening card of the 120-day race meeting at the Michigan Fair Grounds today.

Is man to be denied even the smallest foothold in this quaking bog of modern civilization? Religion is going, the family is going, morals are going, and now milk, butter and eggs are going. The State Medical Society convention at Utica has just been told that many sudden deaths in middle age are due to the fact that people eat too many dairy products.
Miss Julia Donahue gave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino for Miss Jane Erdmann and William L. Burton, who will be married tomorrow in St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Vincent Astor, skipper of the Nourmahal, on which President Roosevelt has made several vacation trips, told the Senate committee investigating ocean and air mail contracts today that he would throw overboard any one who tried to talk business with the President on these trips.

Executive sessions of the Congressional subcommittee investigating Nazi activity in and near New York began yesterday at the Bar Association, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, with Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, chairman of the full committee, presiding, and Representative Samuel Dickstein of New York in attendance.

In many fields of aeronautics the United States stands first, according to the Aircraft Year Book for 1934, which will be issued today by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America. The book, containing 486 pages of reading matter and many photographs and drawings, is the sixteenth edition of the annual.

Fordham's freshman nine yesterday registered its eighth triumph in as many starts this season by vanquishing Textile High School, 8 to 2, at Fordham Field. The victors' offensive was featured by the batting of Warren Mulry, who hit a home run with one on base in the first inning and then collected a double and a single.
