WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Heavy stocks of liquor are accumulating in customs bonded warehouses, principally in New York, Boston and Philadelphia, according to officials.

DETROIT, May 31. -- With delegates from all parts of the country in attendance, the American Socialist party opened its national convention here tonight with declarations by Norman Thomas and other party leaders that President Roosevelt's New Deal had failed and a call to the people to embark upon a clear-cut Socialist program as the only way out of the depression.

An advance of 0.4 point in The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to 111.8 on Tuesday from 111.4 (revised) the Tuesday previous, was due entirely to the sharp advance of the grains and flour under the leadership of wheat.
HAVANA, May 31. -- Dr. Guillermo Martinez Marquez, director of the Spanish daily Ahora, was arrested at noon today by the military authorities and held incomunicado at Cabanas Fortress.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 31. -- Fifty students of the Edgewood Park Junior College, Greenwich, received diplomas this morning at the annual commencement. Dr. Matthew Reaser, head of the college, made the presentation.
Close to President Roosevelt as he reviewed the fleet yesterday from the forward-deck gun platform of the U. S. S. Indianapolis stood a 9-year-old boy.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 31. -- This city defaulted on a $160,000 payroll for municipal employes today, bringing the total of unpaid salaries to $510,000. The solution to the city's financial problem hinges on a conference of city and county officials and officers of the Chase National Bank on loans.
Naturally I had deep interest in the review of the fleet of the American Navy as the magnificent ships, the concentration of power, steamed by the Commander-in-Chief yesterday.

LATONIA, Ky., May 31 (AP). -- In a thrilling finish the Cattell Stable's Elwawa nosed out G.S. Morris's First Entry to capture the Highland Stock Farm Purse, which featured a good post-holiday program here today at Latonia. Mrs. F.P. Letellier's Poet Prince was third.
A recommendation that further sport facilities be developed here is contained in the report, recently issued, of the New York Committee on the Use of Leisure Time, the committee announced yesterday.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 31. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney's entries dominated the openig of the Wilmington Horse Show today, when the Upperville (Va.) horses scored three victories in the seven events on the first day's schedule. More than 200 horses are entered in the three-day show.

American movies, it was stated at the final session of the Presbyterian General Assembly in Cleveland, are a handicap to missionary labors in the Far East. People in Japan and Korea get the idea that all American women are wantons and all American men carry guns.

The Wallace Beery film "Viva Villa'" will begin an engagement at the Capitol today. Everett Marshall, Patricia Bowman and Borrah Minevitch and his "Harmonica Rascals" will be among the stage entertainers.

The next year of industrial progress under NRA should be marked by definite changes in both its substance and its administration, according to an article written for the June 2 issue of the magazine Today by its editor, Professor Raymond Moley.

MILAN, Italy, May 31 (AP). -- Luigi Beccali, Italian Olympic 1,500-meter champion and world's record holder for the distance, today declined an invitation to compete in the United States next month but indicated he might be willing to make the trip this Fall.
Pipe all hands on deck! This was a good yarn until a shipmate came along to spoil a hot debate with a cold fact. It Went something like this:

LONDON, May 31. -- Newspaper comment here shows that much ill feeling has been aroused by the verbal clash between Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, and Foreign Minister Louis Barthou of France at the Geneva disarmament conference.

With large fields nominated for the six regular events and the special women's race which is to open the afternoon, the United Hunts comes back to its Roslyn (L.I.) course for its Spring meeting this afternoon. Added seating capacity and parking space have made the course, laid out on the estate of Hugh A. Murray, ideal for spectators and there is the expectation of a large attendance.

THOMASTON, Me., May 31. -- When Miss May Gould of Boston tried to break a bottle of champagne on the bow of her father's new schooner yacht at its launching here today she missed her aim and the boat slid down the ways unchristened.

The Cunard liner Franconia returned yesterday from a cruise in the Southern Hemisphere lasting four and a half months. Hendrik Willem van Loon, historian, who was a member of the cruise staff, gave thirty-two lectures and six broadcasts during the long voyage.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Charles E. Mitchell, former president of the National City Company of New York, will appear as a witness Monday at a continuation of hearings into the affairs of the Cities Service Company, controlled by Henry L. Doherty and associates. One of the present officials will also testify.

Opposition to the advocates of a higher price for silver was voiced yesterday by Li Ming, chairman of the Bank of China and the Chekiang Industrial Bank, at a luncheon held in his honor at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, by the China Society of America.

Although she is 79 years old and her hair is snow-white, Mrs. Rose Persico of 333 West Twenty-ninth Street, attempted yesterday to rescue Captain James Davies, a next-door neighbor, who had fallen into a tree in her yard while painting the side of his house.

BUENOS AIRES, May 31. -- In a note to the Argentine Foreign Office the Paraguayan Foreign Minister, Justo Pastor Benitez, reiterates Paraguay's threat to abandon the international rules of war and to take reprisals against war prisoners unless Bolivia agrees to cease her aerial bombardment of unfortified towns.

Clearances of both women's and men's wear are now beginning to figure more prominently in the retail picture, with reports indicating that many types of seasonal merchandise are moving more readily from retailers' shelves at the lowered prices.

LONDON, May 31 (Canadian Press). -- Australian bats thundered a reply to Surrey's heavy scoring as their three-day cricket match continued today. When stumps were drawn the score was 475 for seven wickets declared for Surrey; Australians, 406 for three wickets.

Captain Anthony Eden, Lord IPrivy Seal and one of Britain's representatives at the disarmament conference, painted a rather gloomy picture of the meeting's chances of success in a transatlantic address at Geneva, heard in the United States yesterday over a Nationail Broadcasting Company network.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Ogden Mills and his "crew," the framers of the Darrow report on the NRA's operations and "Old Dealers" in general were roundly denounced by General Johnson tonight in a speech before the National Catholic Alumni Federation and broadcast by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Completion of the draw for the Eastern intercollegiate polo championship was announced yesterday by the Intercollegiate Association. The tournament is to be completed on three playing dates, June 9, 13 and 16, and the newest of the entries in the affair plays in the first game.

A plan of avocational guidance which has been worked out by the National Leisure-Time Committee will be presented to Dr. George F. Zook, United States Commissioner of Education, at a two-day conference starting today in Washington to discuss youth problems.

Although she is 79 years old and her hair is snow-white, Mrs. Rose Persico of 333 West Twenty-ninth Street, attempted yesterday to rescue Captain James Davies, a next-door neighbor, who had fallen into a tree in her yard while painting the side of his house.

BUENOS AIRES, May 31. -- In a note to the Argentine Foreign Office the Paraguayan Foreign Minister, Justo Pastor Benitez, reiterates Paraguay's threat to abandon the international rules of war and to take reprisals against war prisoners unless Bolivia agrees to cease her aerial bombardment of unfortified towns.

Clearances of both women's and men's wear are now beginning to figure more prominently in the retail picture, with reports indicating that many types of seasonal merchandise are moving more readily from retailers' shelves at the lowered prices.

LONDON, June 1. -- President Roosevelt's debt message to Congress was welcomed here because it disclosed a readiness to discuss special circumstances with individual debtors although it generally leaves the problem where it was. The Cabinet will discuss the message next week.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Federal Trade Commission is squarely behind the oral ruling given yesterday to the New York Curb Exchange that securities not exempt from registration under the Securities Act of 1933 may not be dealt in legally on a when, as and if issued basis unless a registration statement has been filed and become effective.

PARIS, June 1. -- Miss Helen Jacobs and Miss Sarah Palfrey tonight were resting, but none too comfortably, in the final brackets of the women's doubles in the French hard court tennis championships as the former prepared to challenge Miss Margaret (Peggy) Scriven of England for the singles title tomorrow.
The Board of Estimate authorized yesterday the expenditure of a total of $18,450,000 for current relief expenses, with $17,750,000 of the amount going to provide relief this month.

The appointment of a special committee to devise plans to curb racketeering in the liquor industry was announced yesterday by the New York State Regional Code Authority, Wine and Liquor Division, Wholesale Alcoholic Beverage Industry.

OTTAWA, June 1. -- The appointment of a Canadian to represent the King as Governor General of the Dominion and the substitution of part-time officials for the Lieutenant Governors in the Canadian Provinces are being urged by a number of Ontario newspapers as a result of a recent verbal clash between Lord Bessborough and Mayor William Stewart of Toronto.
ALBANY, June 1. -- The organization certificates of three credit unions in New York City have been filed, the State Banking Department announced today. The concerns and their incorporators are:

The real complaint against advertising is not so much that it is misleading as that it is not sufficiently informative, John Benson, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, told THE NEW YORK TIMES Advertising Club yesterday.

BERLIN, June 1. -- Nothing since Adolf Hitler came into power has created such profound satisfaction in German official circles as the agreement reached at Geneva for a plebiscite in the Saar next Jan. 13.

Consolidated net income of the Long Island Lighting Company and subsidiaries for 1933 amounted to $3,053,681. This was equal after preferred dividends to 48 1/2 cents a share on 3,000,000 no-par common shares, comparing with $4,168,569, or 86 cents a share, earned in 1932.

Again the New York Community Trust has set a new high record in its yearly distribution of proceeds from the funds entrusted to it -- only a slight increase; but any increase in these times has a significance beyond its amount. The total disbursements since 1924, when the trust was founded, have now risen to $1,124,694 and the aggregate value of the funds of diverse size to $7,703,600.

As a member of the present National Labor Board may I Urge strongly the passage at this session of Congress of the proposed National Industrial Adjustment Act? It will not prevent Strikes or the right to strike. But it will be a powerful agency in preventing industrial disputes from reaching the critical strike stage.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 1. -- A New York policeman, George Doyle, on leave for a day, teamed with Paddy Doyle, the veteran professional, and won the Metropolitan P.G.A. amateur-pro one-day tournament at the Briar Hills Golf Club today.
Thursday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted were at the lowest.

ROSLYN, L.I., June 1. -- Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Hutton and Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Durant gave a large luncheon today at Hillwood, the country estate of the former in the Roslyn colony, before the annual Spring meeting of the United Hunts Association, which was held on the estate of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Murray at Westbury.

TRENTON, June 1. -- Senate President Clifford R. Powell of Burlington County charged today that acquisition of the Delaware and Raritan Canal by the State was "the biggest legislative fraud of the year." He gave notice that when the Legislature reconvened next week he would urge that the law passed earlier this year be repealed.

Barney Ross won his lightweight and welterweight championships in separate fights, and that is the only way he can lose them. The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday made the ruling that Ross could sign to defend only one crown at a time and could lose only the one specified in the contract.

The following table gives the amount of the dealings' in the stocks from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily ana weekly transactions:

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Treasury's financing program for June will be announced Monday. Official information was withheld, but the offering is generally expected to take the form of bonds of a maturity of ten years or more, carrying an interest rate of 3 or 3 1/8 per cent.

CLEVELAND, June 1 (AP). -- Another general tie-up of Great Lakes tugs, hampering the movement of bulk freighters at some ports, was in the making today as union tugmen failed to accept a plan of settling a wage dispute with their employers, proposed by a Federal arbitrator.

LONDON, June 1 (Canadian Press). -- With the Australians holding a long lead, the three-day cricket fixture between the visitors and the Surrey County side was left drawn today owing to the time limit.

Seven member lines of the United States Intercoastal Steamship Conference yesterday followed the suit of five other members in filing notice of their intention to withdraw from the conference, effective July 31. Representatives of the lines informed Robert C. Thackara, chairman of the conference, of their desire to protect their interests in case the first five are freed from the tariff rules which now hold the intercoastal freight rates at established levels.
The money market was dull as far as business was concerned and steady in the matter of quotations. Renewals made up the bulk of the day's turnover, little new money being engaged.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Department of Justice, contrary to current reports, has taken no action and has given no advice regarding a possible checking of the anti-Nazi boycott.
GROTON, Mass., June 1. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt dropped official status today to see John, their youngest son, graduate from Groton School as his father was before him.

Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, issued a statement yesterday, following the passage of the revised Stock Exchange Bill by Congress in which he announced that the Exchange "intends to do everything in its power to cooperate with the commission in the administration of the act."

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Representatives of 60,000 workers in thet steel mills of Gary, South Chicago and Calumet City conferred tonight with William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor on plans for a strike in these mills after June 10.

BERLIN, June 1. -- After a prolonged oratorical assault on "reactionary aristocrats, the intelligentsia and the philistine bourgeoisie," the Nazi campaign against "carpers and killjoys" seems to be shifting back again to the Jews.

Barnard College's senior week was formally opened last evening with the traditional step-singing by the entire student body in the quadrangle facing Milbank Hall, Broadway and 119th Street. A senior reception, attended by members of the graduating class, their families and friends and the faculty, was held later in Hewitt Hall.

The right of the Willard Straight Post of the American Legion to reinstatement on the ground that it was unjustly suspended after it had adopted a resolution in December, 1932, opposing an immediate cash payment of adjusted compensation certificates, was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.

Eminent personages in the official, diplomatic, political and social life of the nation joined with a huge throng in the naval pageantry of the United States Fleet Ball in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

MUKDEN, June 1. -- During the past fortnight there have been several attacks by large groups of bandits on trains, stations and villages in Manchuria. At least three of these resulted in partial bandit successes. An attack on a Japanese military train near Hsiaochengtze in the eastern section of the Chinese Eastern Railway on May 26 resulted in twelve Japanese dead and twenty-six wounded.

Good consumer response to clearance offerings of seasonal merchandise featured retail trade in the metropolitan area during the week, according to reports by retail executives here yesterday. Greater activity was noted in men's clothing departments due to the price cuts announced, with a broader movement also of women's Summer ready-to-wear and accessories.

ROCHESTER, June 1 (AP). -- Rochester took to the road tonight, after dropping a 10-to-4 battle to Toronto for an even break in the four-game series. Schott was strong from the third through the eighth inning, while his mates banged fifteen hits off Tony Kaufmann and Ad Liska.

Veterans of the Second Division, A.E.F., will be the guests of Admiral David Foote Sellers, commander-in-chief of the fleet, during their annual convention here from June 7 to 9, inclusive, on the sixteenth anniversary of the Battle of Belleau Woods.

Frank Gillmore was re-elected president of the Actors Equity Association at the annual meeting of that body held yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor. Elected with him were the regular candidates of the nominating committee, including Osgood Perkins, Florence Reed, Arthur Byron and Peggy Wood, vice presidents; Leo Curley, recording secretary, and Paul Dullzell, treasurer.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 1. -- Arthur S. Lane of Arlington, Mass., president of the senior class, president of the undergraduate council and captain of the 1933 football team of Princeton University, was voted by his classmates the "best all-round man," "most respected" and "most popular" of Princeton seniors, it was announced here tonight at the senior class dinner in Madison Hall.

The crews of Manhattan College, Rutgers and Rollins College of Winter Park, Fla., will meet today on the Harlem River in the first De La Salle Regatta, an event which aspires to become an annual rowing classic for small colleges.

JUNE in Jersey. Sunlight on Pompton Lakes. A pastoral picture. The road skirted a shimmering body of water and then turned toward a clump of trees under which nestled a white house with a green mansard roof.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). -Twenty hits off Al Crowder, Jack Russell and Alex McColl gave the Red Sox a 13-to-1 triumph over the Senators today in the opener of their four-game series.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 1. -Twenty-five scholarships and fellowships for graduate students, totaling $15,500, were awarded at Harvard University tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- President Roosevelt in a message to Congress today reporting on the status of war debts owed to this country, said no legislation is "necessary or advisable" at the present time, and repeated his understanding that Congress has the final power to deal with the intergovernmental obligations.

First prize of $50 in the essay contest under auspices of THE NEW YORK TIMES Index was awarded to Hazel Webster Byrnes, librarian of State Teachers College, Mayville, N.D., it was announced yesterday. The second prize of $25 went to Catherine J. Pierce, librarian of Swarthmore College, Swarthmore, Pa.

District Attorney Dodge said yesterday that, at the request of Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan, he had discontinued an intended grand jury investigation of the recent reported statement of I. Maurice Wormser, Law Professor at Fordham University, that "at least one-third of the judges" of this city "and two-thirds of the secretaries of the judges" could be "reached."

NEW HAVEN, June 1. -- The commencement exercises of the Yale School of Music were held in Woolsey Hall tonight. The commencement concert was also given, the students being assisted by the New Haven Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Professor David Stanley Smith, dean of the school.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa sailed last night for the Channel ports with 1,635 passengers, the largest number so far this year. There were 425 in the first class with every berth taken and the company used the chief engineers' and chief officers' cabins to meet the demand.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Government control of manufacture of liquor bottles was proposed to the Federal Alcohol Control Commission today as a weapon against the sale of illicit liquor. The proposal was placed before Joseph H. Choate Jr., director of the FACA, which is conducting, in alliance with Treasury officials, a "no-quarter" fight against the bootlegging and illicit distilling industry.

Although $23,832,274 of new State and municipal bonds and notes will come up for award next week, not all are expected to reach the public. The largest issue, for example, $8,064,000 of the Metropolitan Water District in California, which includes Los Angeles, is expected to be taken by the Public Works Administration at the sale on Friday.

BUFFALO, June 1 (AP). -- Jake Plummer, sensational young outfielder of the Buffalo club, accounted for a personal triumph over Montreal today to allow the locals to square the four-game series. The score was 9 to 7.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 1. -The buildings of Miss Mason's Castle School, destined in the will of the school's founder to become an institution to train women for public life, were opened tonight for a preview of the first exhibition of the newly organized Westchester Institute of Fine Arts.

CONSHOHOCKEN, Pa., June 1. -Two poorly clad, crudely masked bandits robbed a mail messenger of two sacks of registered mail containing $17,000 in currency at the Reading Company's station here today and fled in an automobile with a companion.

Arrangements for the resumption of exports of gold from France to the United States were made yesterday when the franc fell to 6.57 3/4 cents, a price which equaled a premium of 0.8 cent for the dollar and allowed substantial profits in transfers of gold.

DETROIT, June 1. -- The convention of the Socialist party was thrown into wild turmoil tonight, when the Left Wing sought to commit the party to violence, direct action, repudiation of "bourgeois democracy" and the dictatorship of the proletariat.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1. -- A double-play toss that went awry was turned into a veritable parade of enemy runs today at Shibe Park and the Yankees lost to the Athletics in the opening of their threegame series.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, speaking tonight at a convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers' Union, said that labor's philosophy was "to provide a more equitable distribution of the wealth of the nation."

Like hundreds of others, I did not attempt to renew my automobile operator's license until within one week of its expiration. When I applied at the Walton Avenue office of the Motor Vehicle Department I was confronted with a long line. The officer on duty rather rudely informed me that there was no way to secure an application blank other than to remain in line.

BERLIN, June 1. -- Although the German debt conference ended with a compromise solution the success of this proposal will largely depend on two supplementary negotiations already under way between Germany and some of her creditors.

Among the attractions which will close this evening are "Ah, Wildernest!" at the Guild Theatre, after an engagement of thirty-five weeks; "Come What May," at the Plymouth, after three weeks, and the revival of "The Only Girl," at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre, after two weeks.

Two well-known figures in polo were added yesterday to the list of those taking part in the preparations for this year's feature, the East-West matches at Meadow Brook. James C. Cooley was named a member of the selection committee for the East and Neil S. McCarthy of Los Angeles arrived to complete preliminary arrangements for the stay here of the West's team.
Mr. and Mrs. John Calvin Thorne gave a reception yesterday afternoon in their apartment at the St. Regis for some of the visiting naval officers and their wives. Among their guests were:

BRUSSELS, June 1. -- Half of the panel stolen seven weeks ago from the polyptych, "The Adoration of the Lamb," the masterpiece by Hubert and Jan van Eyck in the Cathedral of St. Bavon in Ghent, is believed to have been recovered tonight.

More than 5,000 sailors and their officers will march up Fifth Avenue from Washington Square to Fifty-ninth Street this morning in one of the city's largest naval parades since Admiral Mayo led his blue-jackets up the avenue after the World War.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- A preliminary allotment of $5,476,000 for drought relief in ten States was made today by Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, as the government mobilized to meet the worst Spring dry spell in the country's history.

Convicted of having a stench bomb in his possession, Barney Baker, a former pugilist, received the maximum sentence of six months to three years yesterday in Bronx Special Sessions. This is the first conviction, according to the Bronx District Attorney's office, under a recently promulgated law which makes it a misdemeanor to possess a stench bomb.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- A conference on the threatened textile strike broke up late tonight, with union chiefs and the operators' representatives deadlocked, despite efforts by General Johnson to reach a satisfactory compromise on the proposed 25 per cent production curtailment in the industry.

The Commerce Department, reporting on our foreign trade for April, emphasizes the month's decrease in dollar value, as compared with March, of about 7 per cent, but rightly points out that this reflects merely the quantitative reduction usual at this time of year. Comparison with the corresponding month of other recent years is more interesting.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 1. -Mrs. John Hay Whitney of Upperville, Va., won four of the featured events during the second day of the Wilmington Horse Show today. She missed the coveted Gibraltar Challenge Platter, however, which went to Mrs. William du Pont of Wilmington, who scored with her gray, gelding, Quarryman.

A new department, devoted to the work of contemporary American painters, was opened yesterday by the Jacques Seligmann Galleries, 3 East Fifty-first Street. Among the artists represented in the first group of pictures shown is Tom Delbridge, whose "Lower Manhattan" was one of the paintings which attracted favorable comment in the P.W.A.P. exhibition at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington.

More than $27,000,000 of bonds of the Illinois Central and the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroads, holders of which had been asked to approve an extension of maturity, fell due for payment yesterday. In neither case did the companies pay the face value of the principal of the securities.
iss Cecilia Belmont, whose marriage to Gardner Lothrop Lewis Jr takes place this afternoon, gave dinner last night in the roof garden of the Pierre. Her guests were :
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress on war debts follows:

Denial that cabled instructions to increase prices were for any other purpose than that of stabilizing the rayon industry was made yesterday by Samuel Salvage, president of the Viscose Company of New York, in his testimony before the Federal Trade Commission, at the hearing in the Federal office building, 641 Washington Street.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The story of how President Roosevelt handles official business when away from his desk in Washington was revealed today by Stephen Early of the White House Secretariat in connection with the President's war debt message to Congress.
New York City got its chance yesterday to give the United States fleet a vociferous welcome at close quarters and did so with a will.

CORBEIL, Ont., June 1 (Canadian Press). -- If they live and gain enough strength to travel to Chicago, the Dionne quintuplets will be exhibited at the World's Fair this Summer. While the girl infants continued their hold on life it was announced today that their father had signed a contract for their appearance.
TORONTO, June 1 (AP). -- Miss Elizabeth P. Taylor of Little Rock, Ark., heads the association of the Junior Leagues of America as the organization sets out upon a year of intensified activities.

Five trucks containing general merchandise and a small coupe were hijacked early yesterday from a garage at 44 West Fifteenth Street, used by the Phillips Special Motor Transportation Company, Inc., of Philadelphia, commercial truckers, as its New York depot.
Under the first aggressive buying movement in several months, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced more than $2 a bale yesterday and ended at gains of 27 to 30 points.

GENEVA, June 1 (AP). -- An examination of the Chaco jungle warfare between Bolivia and Paraguay will be made by the League of Nations Council, it was decided today, followed by recommendations for a settlement of the dispute.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

Wages paid by the production, pipe line and refinery branches of the Consolidated Oil Corporation to about 15,000 men were increased yesterday, it was announced at the office of H.F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee. The percentages of increases were not announced, although it was said that the new scales were above the average for the industry.

" Those opposing the St. Lawrence Seaway," says Robert R. Dunn in a letter to THE TIMES, "state their personal and selfish views and local prejudice, and entirely ignore the facts pertaining to this development and its immediate necessity to over one-third of our population."

Frederic W. Erb, who will retire on July 1 after fifty years of service in the Columbia University Library, was honored yesterday at a ceremony in the library at which Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia, presented him with a book of more than 200 letters of appreciation from university trustees, faculty and staff members.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday several changes in memberships and member firms and in securities listings.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Varying business conditions in Latin America were reported today by the Department of Commerce in its weekly survey of the foreign situation.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- The prolonged drought, which has brought the farmers of almost every important North American grain and livestock producing area to a point of despair, was aggravated today as a torrid sun established a new heat record for June in the Middle West.

Merely as part of the anchorage for a great fighting fleet the island of Manhattan must be worth all of the $24 which the Indians got for it. Is there anywhere else in the world such a pictorial setting for a line of warships at rest as the Hudson River, with the Palisades for a backdrop and Riverside Park for orchestra seats?

PHILADELPHIA, June 1. -- A member of the banking firm of Drexel Co., who also is a partner in J.P. Morgan Co., said here today that "the thought of Drexel Co. opening an office in New York has never been considered nor discussed."

TOLEDO, Spain, June 1. -- At a festival held tonight in the National Theatre the gold medal of this historic city was formally presented to Toledo, Ohio, and accepted in the name of the American city by Vice Mayor Charles Hoover.

Ernest Schelling, pianist and conductor, with Mrs. Schelling; Mme. Juan Francisco de Cardenas, wife of the Spanish Ambassador to France, and Mrs. J. Hamilton Lewis, wife of the United States Senator from Illinois, are among those departing today for Havre via Plymouth on the French liner Champlain. Others leaving on the ship are:

The mixture of trends in commodities became more noticeable yesterday, with a sharp rise of cotton and a sudden steep decline in wheat after new high prices had been attained, and traders were puzzled. Rubber, silk and coffee were firm, while cocoa, metals and hides declined on the futures markets.

Brokerage firms were informed yesterday by C.E. Adams, Deputy Administrator of the NRA, that they could cut the salaries of employes earning less than $35 a week without violating the code of fair competition for Stock Exchange firms.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 1. -- Arnold Brilhart, a young bespectacled golfer with no previous tournament background, was a giant killer in the Long Island amateur championship today.

The city won its first wage case in more than fifteen years yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court when Justice Harry E. Lewis held that the prevailing wage rate for machinists in city employ between 1926 and 1932, inclusive, was $11 and not, as the machinists claimed, $13.20 a day. The ruling saves the city $375,000.

SHANGHAI, June 1. -- It has been definitely established that the peasant uprising in the Ilan district near Chiamussu in Northeastern Manchuria has been quelled only after the killing of more than 2,000 Chinese peasants and villagers. The death toll of Japanese soldiers was officially announced as only seventy-five, but a high Japanese official at Mukden admits the Japanese losses were nearer 500 than the announced figure.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 1. -- What was described by C.H. Cahan, Secretary of State, as one of the most stringent company incorporation laws in the world was passed by the House of Commons today after only three days of discussion.

ROSLYN, L.I., June 1. -- To Cito, the big 5-year-old gelding owned by Miss C.K. Dorrance, went today's running of the featured Bowman Steeplechase Handicap at the Spring meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association.

Accidents cost industry in this State during 1933 about $100,000,000, according to statistics issued yesterday by the State Department of Labor. The department pointed out that the public paid an enormous indirect tax every year as the result of industrial injuries and deaths.

With well-rounded fields assembled for nearly every event, the 132d track and field games of the New York Athletic Club will be staged at Travers Island today. The meet looks to be up to the usual standard of the Ladies' Day shows of other years.

NEWARK, N.J., June 1. -- The Bears regained winning form today with a 7-to-4 victory to even the series with the Syracuse Chiefs. Charlie Devens, winning his third staight game, went the route for Newark and yielded nine hits in his home debut.

In his testimony before the Ways and Means Committee with respect to the Silver Bill Mr. Oliphant said that "specific change in policy would simply be to increase the proportion of silver in monetary stocks from 12 to 25 per cent." While it is true that the bill will have the effect of doing this, I believe that Mr. Oliphant should also have mentioned another change in policy which will result.

The first of the monthly index numbers, compiled by Dun's Review, indicates an advance of 1 5/8 per cent in average prices during May. The breadstuffs group advanced 12 7/8 per cent and there were also advances in the meats and miscellaneous groups, offset by declines during May in metals, clothing, dairy and garden products and other foods.

Sharp gains in Home Owners Loan Corporation bonds contrasted with weaker prices for United States Government issues, foreign loans and domestic corporation issues on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The Home Owners Loan Corporation 4s, due 1951, touched a new peak at 101 28-32 and closed at 101 26-32, up 8-32 point on the day.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 1. -Mrs. S. Sloan Colt of Tuxedo Park today showed her veteran saddle horse Kilmacanogue to score her second victory toward winning the junior horse show Challenge Cup in the feature of the first day of the annual Tuxedo Horse Show.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., June 1. -- A burning desire for a printing press prompted a 12-year-old boy to become a potential kidnapper and send a ransom note to Charles M. Hart, architect, of 640 Ely Avenue, threatening to kidnap his daughter, Mary, also 12, a classmate of the boy.

ALBANY, June 1. -- Because of a new outbreak of forest fires today, Governor Lehman issued a proclamation tonight closing to the public the forests of the Adirondacks. He acted on a plea by the Conservation Commission.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 1. -A large assemblage witnessed the opening today of the Tuexdo horse show. Many dinners were given tonight at the Tuexdo Club before the showing of motion pictures taken at the Grand National in England last Spring and this year's Kentucky Derby.
Realty trading in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday was confined to housing properties.

In an address made in this city on the same day that the House of Representatives was hurrying at breakneck speed to approve the new Silver Bill, LI MING, chairman of the Bank of China, discussed the widely prevalent theory that his country would benefit, and its power to purchase American goods would be increased, through higher prices for silver metal.
BUFFALO, June 1. -- Six thousand Boy Scouts of Western New York gave a visual demonstration of the value of Scout training tonight as the annual convention of the Boy Scout Council ended.

WHEN Lord Berners looks at a person he is likely to see a house, either in whole or in part. Places, as he comments, mean more to him than people. The strong grip on his imagination still held by the great house of Arley, where he was born, is plainly evident on most pages of his book, "First Childhood" (Farrar Rhinehart, $2.50).

Violent price movements in the grain market overshadowed in interest the more deliberate downward reaction on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Wall Street attached less importance than it might have done ordinarily to the fall in stocks, possibly for the reason that trading on the Stock Exchange was extremely slow again.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
THE TIMES has always been a friend of Central Park and has given efficient aid in solving important problems. But there are a few minor problems that, it seems to me, deserve consideration:

Officers and men of the United States Fleet will attend a special Pontifical mass tomorrow at 11 A.M. in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The sailors, accompanied by two Navy bands, will come ashore at the foot of West Fiftieth Street and march through that street to the cathedral, where the pews on both sides of the middle aisle will be reserved for them.

A man and his wife were shot and critically wounded by two burglars last night as they returned to their home at 1,664 Hoe Avenue, the Bronx. The burglars escaped by running to the roof and climbing down a fire-escape to a courtyard.

Eighty-seven diplomas, certificates and degrees will be awarded tonight at the commencement exercises of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music in the concert hall of the school at 130 Claremont Avenue.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 1. -Miss Maureen Orcutt, women's metropolitan golf champion, today shattered one of her own course records when she toured the Crestmont Golf Club course in 73, 1 over men's par, to win the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association by 7 strokes.

Widening his drive against what he considers excessive condemnation awards, Corporation Counsel Paul Windels announced yesterday that his office would take immediate steps to reopen or appeal six condemnation cases in Queens in which permanent awards have not yet been entered by the courts.

Children of small families have a better home environment than those of larger ones, are less likely to have physical defects and more apt to be "normal" in conduct, members of the American Psychiatric Association were told yesterday morning at the final session of their annual meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Grain markets continued their sensational upswing early today, and the advance did not culminate until wheat had sold about 4 cents, corn 3 5/8 cents and oats 2 7/8 cents above yesterday's finish and at new high marks for the season.

TOKYO, June 1. -- The question of army and navy interference in politics has been revived by the resignation of the Navy Office spokesman, Rear Admiral Tsuneyoshi Sakano, this morning, under pressure, because he gave out a statement yesterday denying a report that the navy strongly opposed the candidacy of General Issei Ugaki, Governor General of Korea, for the Premiership.

The city and the fleet exchanged visits in about equal numbers yesterday. Some 20,000 officers and men had shore leave; some 25,000 men and women -- with the latter predominating by 10 to 1 -- went aboard the vessels they had left. At least 100,000 others were left waiting on the piers.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the slowest since February, 1933. Sales in May, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 25,343,000 shares, compared with 29,846,502 shares in April and 104,229,094 shares in May, 1933.

MOSCOW, June 1. -- One of the most significant visitors from the Soviet Union to the United States since the Bolshevist revolution will depart for Washington next Thursday. He is Vladimir Romm of the newspaper Izvestia, who will be the first permanent correspondent of the Soviet press in the United States.

Varying factors, some favorable and some unfavorable, made it difficult to chart accurately the state of trade during the week, but the favorable factors predominated, and the general trend continues upward, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

More than 1,000,000 motorists in the metropolitan area had renewed their driving licenses yesterday, it was estimated by I. James Brody, deputy commissioner in charge of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles Headquarters, 155 Worth Street.

Vermont has, always has had and means always to have a sufficient crop of panthers. Ignorant outsiders have been inclined to put the Green Mountain Felis concolor in the mythology and not among the fauna of the State. Chester, in Windsor County, had a testimony meeting the other night.
CINCINNATI, June 1 (AP). -Smashing the ball out of the field for a home run, Gabby Hartnett gave the Cubs a 3-to-1 victory over the Reds today.

Charged with violation of the NRA code for the artificial flower and feather industry, the First American Natural Ferns Company, 345 East 104th Street, has been ordered by General Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, to surrender its Blue Eagle.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- To bring relief to farmers in drought areas, the Federal Government, acting through county committees and Federal directors, today began buying surplus cattle.
BERLIN, June 1. -- Following Reich Bishop Mueller's efforts to "Nazify" the Protestant Church of Germany a complete schism has now taken place.

For the convenience of Summer recreation seekers traveling to and from the Rockaways the Board of Estimate yesterday granted to the Green Bus Lines, Inc., a temporary permit to extend its bus service to the New Lots Avenue, Brooklyn, station of the I.R.T. subway.
The Coaching Club American Oaks, blue ribbon event of the American turf for 3-year-old fillies, will be run today at Belmont Park before one of the most distinguished gatherings of the season.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- President Roosevelt's debts message was hailed by members of Congress as responsive to American sentiment while maintaining a fair attitude toward the debtor nations.

National bank examiners as well as clearing house examiners who visited the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company in December, 1931, and in April, 1932, testified in Federal court yesterday that $1,713,000 of its own stock which the bank had purchased never was listed among its investments.

New securities marketed here in May made the smallest total since February and, as in previous months of this year, were principally State and municipal bonds. The total of $98,615,000, comprising $97,640,000 for thirty-seven bond issues and $975,000 for one stock issue, compared with $172,357,000 offerings in April, when $171,968,000 represented forty-two bond issues and $389,000, two stock issues.

The City College baseball team closed its season by defeating St. John's University, 4 to 2, in a return game at Dexter Park yesterday. The victory was the fifth in fourteen games for the Lavender this season and avenged a 4-to-1 set-back inflicted by the Redmen last month.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- President Roosevelt, who is away from the capital, sent a war debts message to Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Half an hour after Senator Lonergan, Democrat, had bitterly protested today against the administration's handling of patronage in Connecticut, the Senate on his motion unanimously rejected for the second time this week a Roosevelt choice for a Connecticut Federal post.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Brooklyn will have an athletic centre in its Red Hook district after all. Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner and chairman of the Municipal Housing Authority, said yesterday the authority was willing that the Park Department take over fifteen acres of the thirty-eight-acre city-owned tract at the head of Gowanus Canal which had been earmarked exclusively for a model housing site.

Watching the great speculative movement in the grain market, Stock Exchange commission brokers realized yesterday the disadvantages under which they were obliged to do business. The volume of stock trading was much smaller than is required to meet normal "overhead."

Aldermanic President Deutsch and Borough President Levy of Manhattan clashed yesterday during a Board of Estimate discussion on a proposed franchise for the Avenue B and East Broadway Transit Company.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation completed yesterday its first release of a major property by transferring to the Uruguayan Government its system in Montevideo, capital of that republic. Officials here said the property had been transferred but did not give details of the transaction.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 1. -Fly-by-night merchants and those who thrive on "cut-throat" competition are the objects of an ordinance passed tonight by the City Council requiring all who engage in business here to file affidavits with their license applications setting forth that they will operate under NRA restrictions.

Captain Benjamin M. Chiswell, commander of the Eastern area of the Coast Guard and Captain of the Port of New York since 1932, has been "detached" and ordered to Washington, it became known yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Prices of hogs were changed little here today, although the heavier kinds continue to be in best demand. The top was steady with yesterday at $3.75 a hundred pounds and the day's average was unchanged at $3.35.

A prize of $750 for the best novel on "an American proletarian theme" is announced by the New Masses in conjunction with the John Day Company. The contest will close next April 1. The prize will be in addition to royalities, and John Day will publish the winning book.

Admiral David F. Sellers, commander-in-chief of the United States fleet, declared at a naval dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night that if the nation, despite peace pacts and the movement to reduce armaments, should be plunged into conflict, the fleet now in New York waters could be counted on to live up to the navy's greatest tradition -- that it "has never yet engaged in an unsuccessful war."

In reading Mr. Rich's reply to Dr. Samuel Smith's and my own letters, it is evident that we differ in our fundamental concept of education. Mr. Rich believes that "a science [of education] has been in the making for somewhat over a quarter of a century." I think that the science of education has been in the making for many centuries.

LONDON, June 1 (AP). -- A complete revision of the international conventions governing copyright, patents, trade-marks and designs, was agreed to today by representatives of thirty-nine nations after a conference here lasting more than a month.

MOSCOW, June 1. -- Hope of the Soviet Government that Foreign Commissar Litvinoff's proposal for a conference of peace may give the United States an opportunity to cooperate more closely in creating safeguards against war without tying herself up in the League of Nations is seen in editorial comment today in the newspaper Izvestia, government organ.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- By adopting in the House a resolution virtually abrogating the rules of that body, and by forcing through in the Senate an agreement to vote on President Roosevelt's Reciprocal Tariff Bill not later than Monday, Democratic leaders succeeded today in upsetting two anti-administration filibusters, took charge of a balky Congress and drove toward final adjournment, which they still hoped would be not later than June 9.

GENEVA, June 1. -- The serious situation in which the disarmament conference finds itself found expression at the outset of the commission meeting this afternoon in the following carefully prepared statement by Arthur Henderson:

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers.

Manager Bill Terry did a deal of heavy master-minding at the Polo Grounds yesterday while a gallery of 4,000 clamored for results. But at the finish it was the business end of his bat that by far did the more commendable work.

On the application of Vincent Astor, a temporary injunction was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew restraining the removal of the furniture, furnishings and other equipment of the Hotel St. Regis pending a hearing on Monday to continue the restraining order.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 1. -- The movement for a general strike of the 103 local affiliates of the American Federation of Labor received a setback today when the threatened strike of Toledo Edison Company employes was averted by an agreement for a 20 per cent wage increase and other terms regarded as a union victory.

Captain Maurice Rossi and Paul Codos, French round-trip North Atlantic airmen, who are both radio experts, saw radio telephony at its best yesterday. With Commander Yves Donval, commanding officer of the French training ship Jeanne d'Arc, which sails today for Halifax after a world cruise, and his fellow officers and cadet officers, they were guests at luncheon of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company at the company's building, 67 Broad Street.

BOSTON, June 1. -- Win or lose, the Dodgers go in for the unusual. Today they battled the Braves for sixteen innings and three hours thirty-five minutes before subsiding on the short end of an 8-to-7 count, with Manager Stengel sending two invalids and one rookie into the fray before it ended.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., June 1. -- Although he is suffering from a slight cold, Primo Carnera resumed training today for his heavyweight championship bout with Max Baer in the Madison Square Garden Bowl on June 14.
WORCESTER, Mass., June 1. -The White House consists today and tomorrow of a train parked on a railroad siding in the heart of the manufacturing district of this city.

PARIS, June 1. -- A heavy blow was struck today at American hopes of retaining the Wightman Cup, women's international tennis trophy, against England at Wimbledon June 15-16, when Miss Alice Marble's physician announced she must give up tennis for this year.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended May 26 totaled 340,321,000 barrels, a decrease of 1,073,000 barrels from the total of 341,394,000 barrels on hand at the end of the preceding week, Secretary Ickes announced today.

In the determination of the Nazi regime to extinguish freedom of the press in Germany, one important newspaper after another has been subjected to absolute governmental control, and now what appeared to be the lone survivor has met the same fate. For many years the Frankfurter Zeitung was a power not only in Germany but throughout Europe.

Six men were arrested yesterday as leaders of a group of 100 Socialists who held a meeting in front of the Standard Baking Company's plant at 170 Wythe Avenue, Brooklyn, to test the injunction against picketing the plant handed down by Supreme Court Justice Faber.

SYRACUSE, June 1. -- Dr. Leslie A. Bryan, former Syracuse University track star and a member of the faculty and coaching staff for the past nine years, today was named director of athletics and physical education by the board of trustees. He succeeds George B. Thurston, who has been acting director for the past two years and graduate manager for the preceding eleven years.

LOS ANGELES, June 1 (AP). -- At least fifty persons were injured, one seriously, today in a riot which resulted when police broke up a congregation of unemployed in front of the county welfare offices. Three women were arrested.

Kidder, Peabody Co., one of the oldest banking and brokerage firms in the country, will drop its deposit banking business on June 16, the date when the securities business must be separated from the deposit business, under the Banking Act of 1933, it was reported in Wall Street yesterday.
PARIS, June 1. -- The effort by Left forces to hold up an appropriation of 3,000,000,000 francs of additional military credits was defeated in the finance commission of the Chamber of Deputies today.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 1. -- The new America's Cup yacht Rainbow made a better showing today in a renewal of her sail-testing spins off here with the Vanitie.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- How the Associated Telephone Utilities Company supported the market for its own stock during 1930, 1931 and 1932, and caused its investment affiliate to buy common shares from its officers and directors to enable them to maintain brokerage accounts, was described today by Dr. Walter M.W. Splawn in a report to the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Legislative action for the regulation of Stock Exchanges of the country was completed today and the Fletcher-Rayburn Bill will be on the President's desk when he returns to Washington Monday.

PITTSBURGH, June 1 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates rallied brilliantly in the ninth inning today, putting on a three-run drive to win from the league-leading St. Louis Cardinals, 4 to 3, and simultaneously snapping a losing streak that had reached five straight games.

LOS ANGELES, June 1. -- Frank E. Sutton, 48 years old, a mining engineer, was under arrest here today on a Federal indictment charging violation of the Lindbergh kidnapping law in connection with an extortion plot against Fred S. Markham, financier, of Altadena.
May flies have started. Enough said."
ALBANY, N.Y., June 1 (AP). -- Ed Chapman pitched Albany to a 6-to-1 victory over Baltimore in the International League today, giving the Senators the series, three games to one.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Corporation officers and directors and security underwriters will have greater protection than ever from civil liability under the amendments to the Securities Act, Senator Byrnes declared in the Senate today. Senator Byrnes's address came in connection with the adoption by the Senate of the conference report on the Stock Exchange Regulation Bill, to which the Securities Act amendments are appended.
LONDON, June 1 (AP). -- Franklyn L. Hutton found his daughter, Princess Barbara Hutton Mdivani, in a medical clinic here today and was visibly annoyed about something after he visited her.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 2. -- The Aiken Knights, beaten by John Hay Whitney's Greentree quartet on Thursday by an 8 to 4 score, turned around today and defeated their conquerors, 9 to 8, in a hard-fought match on Belmont Field at the Meadow Brook Club.

THE Chevrolet Motor Company last week formally announced the introduction of its Standard Six series to supplement the Master series, introduced at the beginning of the year. Prices of the new models range from $85 to $95 less than those of corresponding models in the Master series, and the Standard is said to be "the world's lowest-priced six-cylinder car."

DALLAS, Texas, May 31. -- Secretary Wallace's "warning" to the South not to be lulled by the present progress of recovery, which was the high note of his recent speech here, left a profound impression. His declaration that sooner or later the South must face the reality hidden from view by such temporary assistance as that afforded by dollar devaluation and government subsidy paid to cotton farmers has started discussion of ways and means.

TOKYO, June 2 (AP). -- Bearing a message from Emperor Hirohito congratulating his fellow Emperor, Kang Teh of Manchukuo, on his recent elevation to imperial splendors, Prince Chichibu, eldest brother of the Japanese sovereign, left Tokyo tonight for a visit to Manchuria.

PHILADELPHIA. TEMPLE UNIVERSITY boasts a "brain trust" of its own. Known as the "X" group because it is an unknown quantity so far as achievements are concerned, this newly formed "trust" is composed of forty young men and women who have been chosen from among 100 outstandingly bright high school graduates of Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware.

An automobile mounted a sidewalk in the Flatbush district of Brooklyn last night and crushed a woman against a telegraph pole, inflicting injuries from which she died a few minutes later in the Kings County Hospital.

In a recent article in your paper you gave the views of a Mrs. August Belmont, president of the Motion Picture Research Council, in which Mrs. Belmont heartily dlsapproved of the present system by which a theatre manager must con tract for certain films before he sees them.

Arkansas is still true to her motto, "Regnat Populus." Her people are still the neighborly individualists that they were in the pioneer days and even in later days when, following the Civil War, citizens served not as "soldiers" but as "farmers" mutually pledged "to protect each other from outlaws who infest the State."
Prices on the Cotton Exchange not only maintained all of Friday's improvement but closed around the top yesterday at additional gains of 11 to 13 points.

Uncertainties in the grain and labor situations, coupled with un-seasonally hot weather, left their marks on the general economic picture last week. Reports from the Federal Reserve centres, however, indicate that in spite of these conditions there was only a slight cessation of the forward movement.

THE vast development program for the West Side of Manhattan is about to take an important step forward. For two years the business depression has helot up the plans in the main. Now the Legislature has made further progress possible.

LONDON, June 2. -- With the reconvening of Parliament this week, British politics is withdrawing into a circumscribed area of domestic affairs which will monopolize attention until the end of the session in August.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Following a telephone conversation with President Roosevelt, Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, made known today that an emergency work program would be started at once in drought-stricken areas to provide cash to destitute families.

A GREAT many books nowadays announce cautiously that none of their characters are real persons -- a statement often only too true. Mr. Hartswick takes a more winning line. He says that "except in the matter of nomenclature none of the characters in this book are fictitious.

TRENTON, N.J., June 2. -- To make fingerprints a badge of honor for law-abiding men, women and children is one of the aims of the new organization called the State Police Executives of the United States.

HERE is a book at once jovial and serious, tender and rollicking, in which a man, come to his later years, sits down and lets cares drift away while he lives for a little while in memories of a happy childhood and youth spent on a Pennsylvania farm.

IN the Valley of Virginia in 1862 a small group of daredevil horsemen wearing the Confederate gray had the audacity to charge a Union column. They struck like a thunderbolt and for a moment did tremendous damage. But greater numbers soon overpowered and captured them.

TOMORROW morning the big drum begins to give up its secrets. The preliminary speeches should be over by a few minutes past 10 o'clock. After that, as fast as the counterfoils come out of the drum, the numbers of the tickets that have dawn horses in the English Derby will be read off by the announcer, and the microphone will carry his voice not only to the back of the hall but to London.

What was it that held millions of people in New York intent and expectant for hours on Thursday? The great naval review, inspected by the President, was, to be sure, a wonderful spectacle. But it was more than that. It was a symbol. In the magnificent display made by the fleet thoughtful observers saw more than an array of fighting ships.

THE month of June will hardly be considered dull in the annals of book auctions. In England and on the Continent the production of sale catalogues proceeds with a feverish intensity suggestive of Summer heat. The most elaborate of these publications, received belatedly, describes the four-day sale just concluded at La Galerie Charpentier in Paris of the beautiful library of Henri Beraldi.

LONDON, June 2. -- Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, who returned today from Geneva, went directly to his home in the country without calling at the Foreign Office. Prime Minister MacDonald is at Chequers, his country home, and other key members of the Cabinet are week-ending in various parts of the country, so there will be no formal consideration by the British Government of President Roosevelt's debt message before Monday.

A motion by Jimmy Durante, comedian, and the National Broad casting Company to dismiss the suit brought against them by Alfred Kreymborg, poet, for an injunction and accounting in connection with the use of three of Kreymborg's poems on the stage and in radio broadcasts, was granted yesterday by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson.

THROUGH no fault of her own, Eleanor Shaler points out in an apologetic and engaging foreword, her story has turned out to be a "very moral" one. This is not to say that it's dull. On the contrary, it is bright and naughty, and gay in a Broadway way.

THE Forty-Niners, post-graduate students of the former Professor Baker's "Workshop" at Yale, will stage eight plays this Summer in an ancient barn, transformed into a quaint colony playhouse, that contemplates the Presidential Mountain Range in New Hampshire from a meadow on the old Chase Farm in Whitefield.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- A weather forecast suggesting general showers over the area of drought on both sides of the international line extending south into Kansas started a selling movement today on the Board of Trade that carried wheat down more than 4 cents per a bushel and corn 3 cents from yesterday's finish, while barley, at the extreme, was off 5 cents, the maximum permitted for one day's fluctuation on the Exchange.

Pending the adoption of a code of fair competition under the NRA, coastal fishermen of Rhode Island, Connecticut, Long Island, New Jersey and Virginia enthusiastically subscribed to a voluntary code of fair practice, otherwise known as a "gentlemen's agreement," at a two-day conference of the Eastern Fisheries Association, concluded yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

A TOUCH of drama was injected into the annual convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers during the past week when Major E.H. Armstrong appeared at the Philadelphia meeting to return the institute's honor medal presented in 1917.

In spite of the warmth of the evening, the Town Hall was crowded last night for the second annual dance recital of the Workers Dance League. The performance was in the nature of a contest in which eight member groups competed for the league's awards.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 2. -- After beating Brown only three days ago at Providence, Captain Eddie Loughlin today pitched Harvard to its first victory over Holy Cross in two years.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 2. -- The second annual faculty-alumni forum will be the opening event of the six-day program arranged for the 187th commencement week of Princeton University.

PARIS, June 2. -- In two surprising reversals of form, Miss Helen Jacobs, United States titleholder, today failed in her fifth bid for the French hard court tennis championship and Jack Crawford, Australian Davis Cup ace, went down to defeat in the defense of his singles crown on the Roland Garros Courts.

SANDS POINT, L.I., June 2. -- The Sands Point Bath Club here was filled to capacity with a record attendance this afternoon and tonight for the formal opening of the season. About 600 members and their guests participated in the festivities, beginning with the initiation of the bar in the new Cafe Mouette, which is decorated to represent a French coast tavern.

ON June 6 a testimonial dinner is to be given at the Plaza Hotel in Hew York City in honor of Thomas Mann, whose new novel, "Joseph and His Brothers," will be published on that day by Alfred A. Knopf. The dinner is given by a group of people well known in the fields of the arts and public affairs.

BERLIN, June 2. -- The Reichsbank announced today that during the week ending May 31 Germany lost 18,600,000 marks in gold and foreign exchange [the mark is worth about 39 cents at current exchange], which reduced the combined coverage of her currency to a new record low of 3.7 per cent.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- The probabilities point to the renomination of Senator Arthur R. Robinson at the Republican State Convention to be held in Indiana next Tuesday, although opposition to him is gathering strength. At the Democratic State Convention, to be held a week later, something approaching more nearly to a free-for-all fight is expected on the effort of the delegates to name a Senatorial standard bearer.

President ROOSEVELT belongs in the class of strong men who are not always photographed with their mouths wide open. Most of his pictures show him smiling, shaking hands, chatting, standing at attention, occasionally engaged in formal discourse.

ANCIENT Santo Domingo Mission, near Brunswick, Ga., will soon be restored by CCC workers. About 374 years old, this Spanish ruin stands on the tip of a 250-acre strip of land recently given to Georgia for a park.
TORONTO, June 2 (Canadian Press) -- Toronto won both games of a double-header from Montreal today, 8 -- 5 and 6 -- 5. The Leafs went nine innings to take the nightcap.

The fleet's in. The Navy's here. New York won't be the same for the next two weeks. There'll be uniforms; excitement, searchlights piercing the blue June nights. There'll be sailors rowing boats on Central Park Lake.

NEWARK, N.J., June 2. -- Mrs. James P. Reynolds, who observed her 101st birthday last April 12, gave a Bible verse party this week at her home, 316 Parker Street, for the Junior Christian Endeavor Society of the Park Presbyterian Church, this city, of which she is the oldest communicant.

SOFIA, June 2. -- There is a saying that every nation gets the government it deserves. Bulgaria unquestionably has needed a government which would suppress political parties, and now she has just that. The new Gueorguieff government, which carried out a military coup d'etat on May 19, is assured of popular support, provided it refrains from abusing its powers.

ROME, June 2. -- It is, perhaps, a pity that Premier Mussolini should have chosen in a speech intended to be a careful analysis of Italy's financial and economic situation to announce a rather sensational rearmament program.

SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO Calif., June 2 (AP). -- Terribly emaciated, Mary Ebarguarry, 7 years old, was cared for at Santa Ana Hospital today while authorities began an inquiry into the alleged imprisonment of the child in a chicken pen by her mother.

EXTENSIVE readjustments in our social and economic system have been predicted repeatedly of late -- or said to be in progress -- by various scholarly bodies, and educators have been advised to reorganize their teaching to harmonize with these changes.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 2. -- With Vic Hanson, varsity football coach, playing the ro1e of hero, the Syracuse University Alumni nine defeated the Varsity, 11-2,before a large Commencement Day crowd at Hendricks Field today.

Eighty-five striking bakery driver-salesmen of Dugan Brothers, Inc., were arrested yesterday morning after they had overturned delivery wagons and stoned the company's plant at South Fifth Street and Marcy Avenue, Brooklyn.

A law to exclude mentally inferior as well as feeble-minded immigrants from this country was urged yesterday by Dr. Clairette P. Armstrong, psychologist of the Children's Court, at the twenty-second annual meeting of the Eugenics Research Association in the American Museum of Natural History.

New York University seniors will begin commencement activities this week with Senior Week getting under way tomorrow in the twelve schools and colleges of the university. Nearly 4,000 students will take part in a series of dinners, dances, boat rides and class day exercises.

MANY people feel that stories about children have been overdone, particularly the sort of book in which the author displays his children with the conscious pride of a showman exhibiting quaint specimens.

The arrival from Hamburg last week of the Hapag-Lloyd liner New York marked the completion of the company's program of rebuilding its four Ballin-type ships, which was started last Fall. The hulls of the New York, Hamburg, Deutschland and Albert Ballin have been lengthened 39 feet 4 inches by the addition of new bows and middle sectors, their speed increased from 16 to 19.25 knots and their propelling power from 15,000 to 20,000 horsepower.

The navy marched yesterday -- and from 500,000 to 750,000 persons who lined Fifth Avenue from Washington Square to Fifty-ninth Street cheered the rolling gait of the sailors, and applauded the rollicking tunes of the sea.

READING a new book by H. R. Knickerbocker is like sitting in a ship's bar with one of those fabulous Englishmen who has been everywhere and known every one and can tell you just what's the significance of everything going on.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Despite the vagaries of a 102-degree heat wave, the merchandising record was unexpectedly good during the last week. When the temperatures toward the end of the week kept many women shoppers at home, all the department stores experienced a big run on lightweight men's suits and trousers, women's Summer apparel and yard goods for Summer dresses.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Debits to individual accounts, as reported to the Federal Reserve Board by banks in leading cities for the week ended May 30, which included five business days in-most of the reporting cities, aggregated $5,334,000,000. or 17 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 6 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

The man whose death is announced in the title of this story is the radio operator on the fruit steamer Napoc, which is on its way from New Orleans to Puerto de Oro in Costa Blanca. Cartwright is the third to die aboard that ship, and all the deaths have been sudden and mysterious.

WESTFIELD, N.J., June 2. -Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York City, defending her title in the fourth annual Anne Cummings memorial tennis tournament for girls, reached the semi-finals through two straight set victories at the Westfield Tennis Club today.

PARIS, May 31. -- Black and white knife-pleated Pierrot frills or double circular organdie bibs are two flattering new neck adornments seen in the Lanvin collection. This couturiere is launching successful variations of the popular drooping cape in models that are cut off square at the waistline in front and which are also square but longer in the back.

LONDON, June 1. -- One of the underlying causes of Latvia's present experiment in getting along without political parties and governing itself without a Parliament was that the national legislature or Saeima was cursed by so many parties it could not function.

BOSTON, June 2. -- Backed by a 12-to-2 lead which his slugging team-mates had amassed by the end of the third inning, Fred Frankhouse today coasted into his eighth straight victory of the season and the Braves' seventh consecutive triumph.

PITTSBURGH, June 2 (AP). -- The Pirates and Cardinals divided today's double-header, St. Louis winning the first game, 13 to 4, and Pittsburgh the second, 6 to 3. Rip Collins was the batting hero of the first game and Wallie Roettger of the nightcap.

TOLEDO, June 2. -- The movement for a general strike of 110 American Federation of Labor units in this city collapsed tonight when strikers at the Electric Auto-Lite Company's plant approved a peace pact drawn up earlier in the day.

A note from Major Maurice Campbell says that Henrietta Crosman, who is Mrs. Campbell in private life, has asked for and received her release from the long-term contract she had with Fox Films. Reason: dissatisfaction with the parts to which the studio has assigned her recently.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 2. -- A.W. (Laddie) Biggs, strapping young Huntington star who won the Long Island amateur crown in 1925 and was runner-up last year, reached the final round of the championship today by eliminating Tommy Tailer in the quarter-final round and Keenan Morrow in the semifinals.

THE early history of Canada is rapidly becoming an attractive field for historical research, but of all the historians who have been delving into it during recent years none has made richer finds than the author of this book, who is by birth a Canadian.

NEWARK, N.J., June 2. -- Because of its situation between two large cities, Philadelphia and New York, the State of New Jersey early became the battleground of the Revolutionary War. For the same reason it is today a battleground of society's efforts to stamp out traffic in illegal alcoholic beverages.

THE Metropolitan Museum's motion pictures will be shown at 2:30 P.M. on Thursdays during the Summer. "The Chronicles of America" (Yale Photo-Plays) will be shown on the first and third Tuesdays of each month at 2:30 P.M.

ONCE the motion picture directors wore riding breeches and shiny putties as the sartorial insignia of their craft. They handled megaphones and tore their pompadours to shreds like mad prophets and winced every time the leading man looked at the leading lady.

AT the dockyards of Dunkerque, the Chantiers de France, lies the somewhat battered 10,000-ton French steamer Tunisie. A thousand eyes a day glance at her and take her for just another freighter which is being reconditioned.

WHEN-Herbert Hoover described the Virgin Islands as an "effective poorhouse," it must be admitted that from a material point of view he spoke the truth. Although the islands are wealthy beyond words in the beauty of their coral reefs, the exquisite coloring of their tropic waters and the charm and character of their people, their economic condition has been deplorable.

The Catholic chaplains with the United States fleet received invitations yesterday from the faculty of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, to attend the commencement exercises of the college on Tuesday afternoon in the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium on the campus.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., June 2. -- Armed with unequaled powers by any other village board in the State, the Pleasantville trustees within the next few days will convene to decide what use they will make of a special bill which permits them to waive penalties and interest on unpaid taxes for years prior to 1934.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 2. -- The baccalaureate sermon by Chancellor Charles W. Flint and the commemoration of the 100th anniversary of the Syracuse Medical College will mark the opening tomorrow of Syracuse University's annual commencement.

Fordham University's baseball team definitely established its superiority for the season over the New York University nine at Ohio Field yesterday. With a barrage of twenty hits, the Maroon captured the second of the two-game series from their Bronx rivals, 19 to 11.

GENEVA, June 2 (AP). -- A frank examination of Franco-British relations is planned, it was learned today, in an exchange of visits between the Foreign Ministers of the two nations. Louis Barthou and Sir John Simon, who clashed spectacularly this week at the disarmament conference.

Justice Albert Conway, in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn, yesterday signed an order directing Mrs. Helene Schaper to turn over to her sister, Mme. Frieda Hempel, the opera singer, a diamond cross and a platinum chain valued at $10,000, in order that the jewelry may be put up at public sale.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Richmond Pearson Hobson, who thirty-six years ago to a day ran the Merrimac into the mouth of Santiago Harbor under the nose of Spanish guns in an effort to bottle up Spain's fleet, was elevated from the rank of resigned captain to retired rear admiral by a viva voce vote of the House today.

THE nation set out years ago for a high goal -- the control of the liquor traffic in behalf of public welfare. Prohibition, an attempt to attain that goal, lacked the support of public opinion and failed. Repeal was the beginning of another drive toward this objective, and was to be followed by the enactment by each State of sensible liquor laws possible to enforce.

THE first anniversary of the entrance of the New York Hippodrome into the field of grand opera will be celebrated tonight with a revival of Verdi's "Masked Ball." On June 3. 1933, Cecil E. Maberry, managing director of the house, brought the Chicago Opera Company, under Alfredo Salmaggi, into the theatre for an indefinite run, which totaled, when the Spring, Summer and Fall returns were in, a period of twenty-five weeks.

HAVANA, June 2. -- A decree restricting the exportation of funds from Cuba was signed today by President Carlos Mendieta. Restrictions on banking operations were regarded as the first step toward the creation of a Cuban bank of issue.

Mayor LaGuardia will take advantage of the expiration of the term of John J. Keller, Brooklyn Republican, as a member of the Municipal Civil Service Commission to appoint a succcessor of his own choice, it was learned yesterday.
