POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 4. -- This riverside city again became the rowing centre of the country today as California, Columbia and Pennsylvania oarsmen dipped their blades in the waters of the Hudson and started preparations for the renewal of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta here on June 16. California, the first of the Western crews to arrive, had time for two workouts.

PARIS, June 4. -- Whether Chancellor Hitler of Germany has a right to prevent the French people from reading an unexpurgated edition of his book, "Mein Kampf," was thrashed out before the Tribunal of Commerce today.
OMAHA, June 4 (AP). -- A veteran of both the Blue and the Gray, Henry Stephen Smith will receive in death the honors that were denied him while alive.

The new archaeological argument that Exodus occurred in the thirteenth instead of the fifteenth century B.C. is based upon the assumed proof that the Edomites and Moabites were not at the earlier date in Southern Transjordania, and so could not have said to the Israelites recorded in the Book of Numbers, "Thou shalt not pass "through me, lest I come out with a "sword against thee."

The New York Central Railroad will ask the city, in a formal request to be made some time this month, for an extension of time in which to complete the $180,000,000 West Side improvement, on which work was started in 1929.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP). -- Slightly more than half of the relief funds expended in the United States during the first three months of this year was provided by States and local communities.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 4. -- J. Alexander McWilliams, Princeton junior from Dwight, Ill., was elected to captain the 1935 Tiger track team at a meeting of the lettermen today. The new leader is a star pole vaulter.

NEWARK, N.J., June 4. -- After a week-end spent in remorse and the fear of police suspicions, Arthur Dunn, 19 years old, of 2,244 Watson Avenue, the Bronx, walked this morning into the offices of the R.L. Watkins Company, 360 Elizabeth Avenue, where he was employed as a clerk, and confessed he had stolen the $2,741.68 payroll cash which he reported had been taken from him Friday by bandits.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 4. -- Owen D. Young, in a Commencement Day address delivered here today at the University of Nebraska, which conferred upon him the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws, defended President Roosevelt's "brain trust" and declared that the New Deal had to come.

The first witness in defense of Joseph W. Harriman yesterday was Frederick W. Scholz, a certified public accountant, who traced the steps in Mr. Harriman's attempt to preserve public confidence in the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company after the market crash of 1929 by taking its stock off the market at $1,500 a share whenever it appeared.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., June 4. -- The annual Spring sports dinner was held at the Lawrenceville School tonight. Letters were awarded to sixty-nine athletes and captains and managers for nearly all teams were announced. A.R. Hyatt, acting headmaster and director of athletics, presided.

The navy continued to play host to New York yesterday, but only a fraction of Sunday's record-breaking throngs took advantage of the afternoon visiting privileges and boarded the ninety ships of the fleet.

GENEVA, June 4. -- For four hours this afternoon the hardworking bureau or steering committee of the Disarmament Conference, with only the official rapporteurs of its various delegations present, tried to debate its way out of the deadlock in which the conference finds itself.

The temporary injunction order signed last week by Supreme Court Justice Leander B. Faber against Local 505 of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union was indirectly upheld by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday.

This city plans to collect hundreds of thousands of dollars in water main taxes it has discovered are due from large industrial plants, including telegraph and electric companies and other corporations using sub-surface systems. This was announced yesterday by Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of the Department of Gas, Water Supply and Electricity.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- The drought and a desire of producers to get the bonus of $5 a head on hogs from the government under the hog-corn production control contracts have combined to swell the movement of hogs to terminal markets.

The Works Division of the Department of Public Welfare announced yesterday that plans were being made to use swimming pools of East Side welfare organizations for the treatment of children suffering from the effects of infantile paralysis.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- Seven awards were announced today at the International exhibition in lithographs, etchings and wood engravings, which is being held at the Art Institute in connection with the Century of Progress Exposition. There were 412 entries, many of them from foreign countries, including France, Germany and Russia.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP). -- Business and civic leaders of New York City asked a Senate subcommittee on commerce today to reject the plan for a bridge over the North River at Fifty-ninth Street, between Manhattan and New Jersey, pleading with Chairman Sheppard "not to dump railroad freight on the best streets of New York."

A "most impressive turnabout" in the earnings of. department and specialty stores featured last year, marking the first reversal of the steady downtrend which had persisted since before the depression, according to the annual study, issued yesterday, made by the Bureau of Business Research of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, in cooperation with the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 4. -- Dropping off today for a bit of unneeded exercise in an exhibition with the Holy Cross College team, the Dodgers departed for Philadelphia this evening with very red faces.

HARWICH, England, June 4. -- The America's Cup challenger Endeavour sailed to victory in a fine race against three other big yachts today, beating King George's famous old cutter Britannia by more than five minutes. Candida was third and Astra fourth.
WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Following is the text of the British note on war debts delivered to the Secretary of State today:

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP). -- Nate Brown of Washington tonight won a decision from the veteran Johnny Risko of Cleveland in a ten-round fight that featured resumption of legalized boxing in the District of Columbia.

Michael Schaap, president of Bloomingdale Brothers, and Herbert L. Redman, general manager of Saks Thirty-fourth Street, were inducted into honorary membership in Eta Mu Pi, honorary retailing fraternity of the New York University School of Retailing, at the society's annual dinner last night at the Berkeley Hotel, 20 Fifth Avenue.
James P. Marquand, who has set most of his writings against a New England background, is in China searching for material for a novel.

A technical research laboratory, the Police Department's newest weapon in its fight against crime, was dedicated yesterday by Commissioner O'Ryan. The laboratory is located in the Police Academy and is the first of its kind in this country.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 4. -- Two championship competitions featured the opening day of the sixteenth annual West Point Horse Show today. The largest attendance in many years applauded notable victories by Ulic and Captain Kidd over the most picturesque courses of the Eastern horse show circuit.
CORBEIL, Ont., June 4 (AP). -- With better arrangements for taking care of the Dionne quintuplets, Dr. A.R. Dafoe was hopeful today that he will be able to bring about improvement in their condition.

An East Side deal which was said to reflect improvement in the Manhattan realty market was closed yesterday. In a transaction negotiated by William S. Sussman, Inc., Willard U. Taylor added to his real estate investments by the purchase of the twenty-story building at 423-27 Fourth Avenue, northeast corner of Twenty-ninth Street.

More than 100 couples attended the annual senior promenade of the graduating class of Columbia College, given last night in John Jay Hall on the Morningside Heights campus. The dance, held in honor of the seniors, marks the end of social activities at the college for the present academic year.

There has been definite economic, social and moral improvement throughout the State since repeal, according to replies from county alcoholic beverage control boards to a questionnaire sent out by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

In the discussion and proposals concerning a new charter for New York, I notice the absence of mention of city planning. Naturally, the whole country is interested in the charter of its largest city, and I would like to point out briefly the very serious mistake which would be made if the new charter does not provide for an official planning agency.

Members of the Recovery party will unite with Tammany "only if Tammany selects a leader whom intelligent and decent voters can support," James J. Hoey, Collector of Internal Revenue, said last night before a meeting of 400 members of the Recovery Club, Ninth Assembly District, at the Riverside Democratic Association, 632. West End Avenue.

The Beaux Arts Institute of Design, 304 East Forty-fourth Street, awarded its annual Paris Prize in sculpture last night to Joe M. McIntosh, 28 years old, of 41 Commerce Street. The prize amounts to $1,200 and entitles the winner to study three months at the Fontainebleau School of Fine Arts, France, and to visit other foreign countries.
Journal of a week-end expedition to Catskill Mountain streams in search of trout:

TRENTON, N.J., June 4. -- The Assembly voted impeachment of John McCutcheon, former State Controller, and William B. Harley, former Passaic County Judge, tonight after a committee investigating charges of corruption submitted its report.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Never was so well-publicized a man so neglected by the Washington newspaper corps as was John Maynard Keynes, who spent five or six days here last week. If a report in usually well-informed circles is accurate, that was poor judgment on the part of the correspondents.

Berkeley Bell, third seeded player, who was making his first appearance in the tournament, defeated three opponents yesterday to advance a round ahead of the field in the seventeenth annual Brooklyn tennis championship at the Terrace Club of Flatbush.

The dense fog that enveloped the entrance of New York Harbor early yesterday caused a collision between a freighter and an oil tanker off Ambrose Channel and delayed navigation for five hours. The collision involved the outbound tanker Chiloil and the incoming Norwegian freighter Cubano.

PENNINGTON, N.J., June 4. -- The seniors of Pennington School held their class day exercises this evening in the Shaw Memorial Chapel. An address by Norman J. Leavitt, president of the class, featured the program, which was made up of musical selections, the reading of the class history by Rodney G. Jones and the singing of the class song.

A national system of planned economy can be carried out in the United States without resorting to dictatorship, Professor Calvin B. Hoover of Duke University declared yesterday in the Phi Beta Kappa oration at the annual open meeting of the Columbia chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, national honorary fraternity, in Philosophy Hall at the university.

In reporting that the volume of business fell yesterday to the lowest level in ten years, the Stock Exchange merely repeated a statistical announcement that has been made at least twice recently. It all means that the market is just now in the doldrums to the extent that it was in June, 1924.

A suit to set aside the will of Mrs. Florence Adelaide Pratt, widow of Henry Pratt, New York attorney, and a daughter of the late Isaac Singer, inventor of the sewing machine, was started yesterday before Surrogate James A. Foley.

The youth of America must look to President Roosevelt's "courageous leadership" for guidance out of these troubled times and for the creation of those opportunities which young men and women must have in order to achieve successful lives, Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle last night told the graduating class of La Salle Academy.

WESTFIELD, N.J., June 4. -- Miss Charlotte Glutting of the Rock Spring Country Club led the field with a 79 at the end of the first day's play in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association closed championship at the Shackamaxon Country Club today.

LONDON, June 4. -- Denny Shute, the titleholder, heads the record entry list of 313 for the British open golf championship to be played at Sandwich in Kent during the week beginning June 25. The list was issued today. Other Americans named are Gene Sarazen, Joe Kirkwood, Macdonald Smith, W.E. Mehlhorn and Charles Lacey of Lakeville.

LONDON, June 4. -- King George led a cavalcade of princes, nobles and officers down the Mail today to review the trooping of the colors, England's most brilliant military spectacle, which is held each year to celebrate the King's birthday.

Indicative of growing investment interest in the Fifth Avenue section close to Rockefeller City was the sale yesterday of the five-story dwelling now remodeled for business at 3 East Fifty-first Street adjoining the former Union Club building on the Fifth Avenue corner.

LONDON, June 4. -- The effects of the drought in the United States are being watched closely today by experts here who are still striving to prevent the break-up of the international wheat agreement of last August.

Many friends of Mr. THOMAS will be surprised, and others pained, when they read of his going over to the extreme Left Wing of the Socialist party. How could he, long the champion of peaceful and democratic methods in bringing about political and social reform, support a resolution declaring that "The "Socialist party, whether or not it is a "majority, will not shrink from the "responsibility of organizing a govern-"ment under the workers' rule"?

B.E. Hutchinson, chairman of the board of the Plymouth Motor Corporation, announced yesterday that record production for this year made it possible "to offer new low prices" with reductions ranging from $20 to $45 on the various types of cars.

Subcommittees appointed by the three regional railway coordinating committees are to meet in Chicago this week to frame a reply to the suggestion of Joseph B. Eastman, Federal coordinator, that railroads place their merchandise services under the control of two competitive agencies.
Six Manhattan properties and three Bronx parcels were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. One scheduled Bronx sale was adjourned. The results were as follows:

LONDON, June 4. -- Gold mining shares continued active today but other sections of the Stock Exchange were dull. Industrials felt the effects of liquidation which caused substantial declines in leading issues. International stocks also were depressed, losing early gains.
More than a dozen artificial elements have been created by experimental physicists both here and abroad since the end of January this year by methods similar to those employed by Professor Fermi.

BERLIN, June 4. -- The freedom of science as against Nazi effort to make it the jade of the Third Reich was defended in a suave but nevertheless pointed manner at the Congress of the Kaiser Wilhelm Society for the Advancement of Science at Dusseldorf today. The speaker was Professor Max Planck, the president of the society, who is dean of German physicists and is famous for his quantum theory.

Confusion which has prevailed in Wall Street concerning the provisions of the National Securities Exchange Bill with regard to margins was partly cleared away yesterday by a statement interpreting that section of the measure by the Association of Stock Exchange Firms.

The sharp curtailment of production of musical shows during the season of 1933-34, which has just closed, is reflected in the report submitted by Dorothy Bryant, executive secretary of the Chorus Equity Association, at the annual election and meeting yesterday afternoon.
NORMAN, Okla., June 4 (AP). -- Seven members of a seismograph oil exploration party were killed in an accidental explosion of a roadside dynamite magazine eight miles southeast of here late today.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- Plans to adopt a strong platform declaring opposition to some of the New Deal measures are taking precedence over the efforts of the party leaders now here to select a chairman of the Republican National Committee to succeed Everett Sanders, who will present his resignation to the committee tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The advisability of consolidating the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway with The New York Central System, including the Big Four and associated companies, was suggested today in a report to the directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation by its railroad division.
Several flats and a variety of dwellings Were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- Reports of rain over a wide area, while indicating that the precipitation had been relatively light, more than offset today sensationally bullish crop comments on the small grain crops on the Board of Trade and at no time were wheat and corn prices above the finish on Saturday.

The June Ball for the benefit of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's clubs for unemployed girls, held at the Waldorf-Astoria last night, was marked with brilliance and many novel features of entertainment. In the throng that participated were dignitaries of the navy and army, high officials of the State and city and many personages of social prominence.

Degrees will be conferred by Columbia University today upon 4,614 students and post-graduate students at the 180th annual commencement exercises. Diplomas and certificates totaling 471 also will be awarded.
WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Great Britain announced suspension of her war-debt instalment payments to the United States in a note sent by the British Embassy to the State Department today.

PARIS, June 4. -- Professor Georges Claude, French scientist, read a paper today before the Academy of Sciences in which he announced that he had found a practical means of making electric lights more powerful with the same expenditure of current.

The Treasury's quarterly financing indicates two purposes -- to take advantage of a very low money rate and a very good market for United States Government securities, and to extend the policy of funding short loans into long maturities. Most of the outstanding long-term issues have lately sold on the Stock Exchange at the highest prices in their history; that is true even of the twenty-year 3 per cents put out in September, 1931.
THE pause in the big league firing provided an opportunity for checking over that queer jumble of statistics known as "the averages." Oddities are sprinkled here and there, as usual.

STONY BROOK, L.I., June 4. -- A.W. (Laddie) Biggs, who annexed the Long Island amateur championship yesterday at Hempstead, today paired with Jim Barnes of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club to finish in a three-cornered deadlock for leading honors in a pro-amateur tournament at St. George's Golf and Country Club.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 4. -- The Citizens Commission on Reform of Westchester County Government was asked by the Board of Supervisors this afternoon to report speedily on whether it can send a bill to the forthcoming special session of the Legislature to provide for the creation of a county executive for Westchester.

PARIS, June 14. -- In the collection of Professor Albert Einstein's writings and sayings that has just been published in France under the title "How I See the World," Professor Einstein, who has often shown appreciation of the American people, is critical of the American policies with regard to disarmament and debts.
PARIS, June 4 (AP). -- The Davis Cup is due to take a long, long ride -- perhaps as far as the United States -- European tennis writers predicted today.

Mr. OWEN YOUNG never gives his mind to a public address without producing something worth hearing and reading. Yesterday at the University of Nebraska he took occasion to paint for the graduating class a picture of what had happened in this country since he himself was leaving college forty years ago.

Borrowings on collateral by members of the New York Stock Exchange carried in New York decreased $71,839,673 in May to $1,016,386,686, according to the monthly figures announced yesterday by the Exchange. This decrease canceled the greater part of the increase which occurred in April, when member loans expanded from $981,353,948 to $1,088,226,359.

LONDON, June 4 (Canadian Press). -- Most owners, trainers and turf writers tonight were of the same opinion as Lord Glanely -- that his unbeaten colt Colombo is going to win the 155th renewal of the Derby at Epsom Downs on Wednesday.

A stone hurled through the show window of Raymond-Whitcomb, Inc., travel agents, of 670 Fifth Avenue, at some time early yesterday morning, enabled a thief to obtain a rare rare Mayan relic worth $5,000.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 4. -- Walter H. Smith Jr., Princeton sophomore from Pelham, N.Y., was elected president of the "Theatre Intime," undergraduate dramatic association for next year, it was announced here today.

With silk, hides and cocoa moderately firmer yesterday, other staples eased on the commodity futures markets or were mixed in trend. Trading was quiet in most instances. On the cash markets there were no advances, but declines occurred in all the grains, sugar, lard, tin, rubber and cotton.

Confronted with a deficit because of the cut in State aid for education and with demands for extension of school services, the subcommittee of the Board of Education's finance committee opened preliminary hearings on the 1935 public school budget yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 4. -- Rain in widely scattered parts of the Middle West today provided some relief from the drought. Showers fell in eastern and southern Illinois and in Cook County and Chicago.
Activity in commercial paper continued to feature business in the money market. Elsewhere Stock Exchange call loans, maturity money and acceptance markets were dull and without change in quotation.

MANILA, June 4. -- The Philippine Islands ballot tomorrow, after the bitterest provincial and legislative election campaign in their history, involving a fight over leadership between Senator Manuel Quezon and the Sergio Osmena-Manuel Roxas group.
A police emergency squad was called upon yesterday to assist in saving the life of a patient on an operating table in Misericordia Hospital, 531 East Eighty-sixth Street.

Alexander Smallens, who will direct the operatic productions of the Stadium Concerts this Summer, is one of the regular conductors of the Philadelphia Orchestra and not an assistant conductor, as previously stated in a comment upon the Stadium's forthcoming season.

ALBANY, June 4 (AP). -- The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court today affirmed the State Tax Commission's income tax of $83,062.63 on the sale of the Vanderbilt mansion at Fifty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue, New York City.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4. -- More than 2,000 convention delegates fought a battle of ballots here today for control of the Interstate Milk Producers' Association, which markets the milk for 22,000 producers in the Philadelphia milk shed.

With the object of curbing the spread of foreign political propaganda here, Bernard S. Deutsch, Aldermanic President, called a meeting yesterday of foreign consuls, who will assemble at City Hall tomorrow.

After an airplane trip from Atlanta Federal penitentiary, James J. Quinlivan, 43 years old, a dismissed patrolman of 322 East 242d Street, was arraigned yesterday before Judge Rosalsky in General Sessions on a conspiracy and two perjury indictments growing out of Samuel Seabury's investigation of the magistrates' courts in 1930.
" And who is that distinguished-looking person on the platform?" said Alice. The March Hare stared at her.

Inquiry among the thousands that visited the aircraft carrier Saratoga yesterday, jamming West Fiftieth Street, the pier and the flight deck of the giant craft, revealed that New York had turned out to visit the fleet for many varied reasons.

MADISON, N.J., June 4. -- Fifty-nine degrees will be awarded tomorrow at the annual commencement exercises of Drew University. The Rev. Dr. Arlo A. Brown, president of the university, will confer the degrees. The Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman of the Central Congregational Church of Brooklyn will be the principal speaker.

The trial of ten Communists and sympathizers before Magistrate August Dreyer on disorderly conduct charges growing out of the rioting in front of the Welfare Department offices eleven days ago was shifted yesterday to the quarters of the Homicide Court at 301 Mott Street.

TORONTO, June 4. -- Smiling and happy at being named in the King's birthday honors list, 73-year-old Miss Margaret Marshall Saunders was up until the small hours of this morning receiving the congratulatory messages of friends in Canada and the United States. She was named a Commander of the Order of the British Empire.
The "Showboat Revue" will open this evening on board the Buccaneer at Tappan Zee. There will be two performances, the first being in honor of a group of officers from the fleet.

Heading a field of eight bidders, a syndicate composed of Lehman Brothers, Phelps, Fenn Co., the Boatmen's National Bank of St. Louis and M.E. Traylor Co. and Sidlow, Simon, Day Co. of Denver, won yesterday the award of a new issue of $500,000 city and county of Denver (Col.) relief bonds due on June 1 from 1944 to 1949. The price paid was 100.4576 at 3 1/4s.

TRENTON, N.J., June 4. -- Before adjourning tonight the Senate passed the appropriations bill for $19,000,000 to operate the State government, the Delaware-Raritan Canal Bill and an amendment to the Dog Racing Act.
The Home Owners Loan Corporation announced yesterday that it had received orders from Washington to proceed with loans for the renovation of homes in New York State.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Norman H. Davis, Ambassador at large and chief United States delegate to the general disarmament conference at Geneva, will take part in the preliminary conversations at London preparatory to the naval limitation conference to be held next year and will cooperate with Ambassador Robert W. Bingham in the informal negotiations as the representative of President Roosevelt.

Eleven office employes of the Macauley Company, publishers at 381 Fourth Avenue, went on strike yesterday in protest against the discharge last Friday of Miss Dorothy Rimmer, a bookkeeper. The strikers contended that Miss Rimmer was let out in retaliation for her activities in organizing the employes into the book section of the Office Workers Union.

John Greenough, retired banker, honorary president of the American Geographical Society and last survivor of the class of '65 of Harvard, who died on May 4, left his entire estate to his widow, Caroline H. Greenough, of 38 East Sixty- third Street, it was learned yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogates' Court.

One of the dullest stock markets in a full decade produced only a few changes of consequence in quoted prices yesterday. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange was 360,000 shares, compared with 626,000 shares on Friday, the last previous five-hour day.

P.A.S. Franklin, president, told stockholders of the International Mercantile Marine Company at their annual meeting in Hoboken yesterday that this year holds little promise of improvement. He submitted the annual report of the company and its American subsidiaries, which showed a loss of $1,411,441.40 in 1933, as compared with a loss of $1,507,187.37 the previous year.

GENEVA, June 4. -- The eighteenth International Labor Conference opened here this morning with some 500 delegates present and with many speeches. In its first day this conference produced documents in foolscap size to the aggregate thickness of one inch.

Four men -- an industrialist, a banker, and two members of the Federal Trade Commission -- will receive offers of posts on the Securities and Exchange Commission, which will administer the Fletcher-Rayburn Act, it was reported yesterday in Wall Street.

HAVANA, June 4. -- All Cuban banks today refused to issue drafts or effect exchange operations, declining to accept responsibilities implied in Saturday's decree restricting exportation of money from Cuba. It is expected this suspension of operations will continue until the government issues regulations and clarifies the law.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 5 (AP). -- All the warships of Japan's mighty navy, anchored at bases throughout the Island Empire, fired a simultaneous salute at 8:30 A.M. today to Marquis Admiral Heihachiro Togo, the nation's naval hero, for whom a state funeral was being held here.

Thomas Mann, Nobel Prize winning German novelist, now a voluntary exile from Nazi Germany, last night exhorted American men of letters to join in a relentless fight against what he described as "the powers of darkness."

DETROIT, June 4. -- The membership of the Socialist party throughout the country is to have an opportunity to pass on the radical declaration of principles adopted by the party convention here yesterday and which has brought the party to the brink of a split.

Prices of high-grade bonds were steady to firm on the Stock Exchange yesterday in the slowest trading since May 21. Bonds of lower credit ratings were generally easier, but the setbacks were of small consequence. United States Government bonds were generally higher on the announcement of the Treasury's mid-June financing plans, closing up 7-32 to down 6-32 point.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 4 (AP). -- Staging a home-run attack that accounted for seven of their tallies, the Rochester Red Wings made it two out of three over the Buffalo Bisons by taking the final game of the series tonight. Nearly 14,000 spectators saw the Wings win by a score of 8 to 3.

The list of the White Star liner Olympic, due tonight from Southampton via Cherbourg, includes Luis Calderon, Spanish Ambassador to the United States; Frederick Toppin, retired vice president of the United States Lines, and the following others:

Dr. Corrado Ricci was regarded as one of the leading Italian authorities on archaeology. One of his most spectacular projects, although perhaps not so archaeologically important as some of his other work, was the draining of Lake Nemi to disclose the sunken galleys of Caligula, which had been hidden for more than 1,800 years.

Authors joined eleven employes of the Macaulay Company in picketing yesterday the building at 381 Fourth Avenue, where the publishing company has its offices. The workers went on strike on Monday following the discharge of Dorothy Bimmer, a bookkeeper and an active organizer of the Office Workers Union.
A group of photographs by Yose Amemya will be placed on view today at the Ferargil Galleries, to remain until June 16. His exhibition has been installed downstairs, in the sculpture room.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- While the members of the Republican National Committee were still mulling over their division into rival camps of "Hoover men" and another insisting that new and preferably Western names have a chance at the party's chairmanship, a new jolt to party serenity knocked on the doors of their closed room in the form of a delegation from the Young Republican League.

The mercury rose to 83 degrees at 3 P.M. yesterday, seventeen degrees above normal for the date and nine degrees above the June day's usual temperatures. But still it was not so hot, Burton Salisbury, night forecaster at the Weather Bureau, declared.
The British note should prove of enormous educational value in a matter of prime importance to recovery concerning which the facts have been largely forgotten or confused.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Postmaster General Farley went to the Capitol today to see what could be done with some Senators whose patronage requests have been disregarded.
ST. JOHN's Nfld., June 5 (Canadian Press). -- The Labrador gold rush has subsided and Newfoundland's new Commission Government is notifying prospectors that their licenses have been terminated.

The Chicle colt Roustabout, which carried C.V. Whitney's colors to second place in the Withers, was a driving winner in the thirty-fourth running of the Swift Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park. Coming from behind in a great rush, Roustabout was just up to score by a head over Marshall Field's Gentle Knight, which had set the pace from the start.
Money market was quiet all day and made up chiefly of renewals. Quotations for all classes were carried forward without change.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 5. -- George B. Cortelyou of New York, president of the Edison Electric Institute and of the Consolidated Gas Company, expressed opposition today to too rigid governmental control of industry which, under political pressure, "develops into an instrument of repression that will cancel its theoretical advantages."

BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 5. -- Members of the Bryn Mawr graduating class of eighty-seven members had their final class ceremonies today, preparatory to receiving degrees at tomorrow's commencement exercises.

The report of the International Paper and Power Company and subsidiaries for the first quarter of 1934 reveals that $1,000,000 of bank loans was paid off by the International Paper Company in April in addition to a reduction of $1,166,703 effected in the first three months of the year, leaving $16,385,559 outstanding.

A feature of Columbia University's commencement day yesterday was the presentation by President Nicholas Murray Butler at noon of craftmanship awards to twenty-one men of various trades chosen for their outstanding work on the construction of the new library.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, June 5. -- The man accused of the murder of Dutch Marie Schmidt, Frank Adam and Fiddler John Holmberg and of the robbery of about $18,000 in gold dust was known in Alaska as the Blueberry Kid, who also gave his name as Tom Johnson, according to P.G. McGuire of Ketchikan, who worked on the case for the government.
EASTON, Pa., June 5. -- In Mr. Davis's death intercollegiate football lost one of its most ardent supporters and its able historian.

Scouts report that Max Baer has been covering up and hiding his high lights under a bushel at Asbury Park for the purpose of misleading the Carnera camp into believing that Max will be just a June order of strawberry shortcake or the voluminous Venetian to engulf with ease.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for authority to turn over to the Republic of Haiti without cost some buildings and equipment which a detachment of United States Marines will leave behind in October when it departs after an occupation lasting twenty years.

For the second time, a jury in General Sessions late last night brought in a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree against Vincent Walsh, 21 years old, for the murder of Patrolman Joseph Burke in a speakeasy hold-up in 1932. The first conviction had been set aside on appeal.

Germaine Schnitzer, concert pianist, won a verdict for $150,000 for injuries in a taxicab accident from a jury before Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller yesterday, but will collect little or nothing.
When James J. Walker was Mayor of New York his sartorial fame carried Sam Greenhouse along to glory with the natty suits, the startling cravats and unique shirts.

LONDON, June 5 (AP). -- A detachment of a thousand special police patrolled the historic Downs tonight, riding herd on the great encampment of gypsies, bookies, tipsters, carnival folk and others drawn to the running of the famous Derby.

Mr. and Mrs. Karl Bukley Pocock of Cleveland gave a dinner last night in their apartment at the Waldorf-Astoria for their daughter, Miss Helen Pocock, and Herbert Neal, who will be married today. The others guests were:

OSSINING. N.Y., June 5. -- Albert Justinano, 15 years old, of 1,409 Neptune Avenue, Coney Island, was drowned today in the private lake on the estate of Forrest H. Figsby, Somerstown Road, Brookside, near here. The boy, with others in his party, had been chased off the grounds by the caretaker but returned despite the warning.

TRENTON, June 5. -- An injunction was asked today by Assistant Attorney General J. Raymond Tiffany to restrain Sears, Roebuck Co. from selling automobile tires at prices lower than set by the State Retail Rubber Tire Trade Code.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 5. -- Two more fleets of eight-oared shells swelled the colony along the banks of the Hudson today and joined in the preparations for the intercollegiate regatta.
The full text of the address by President Nicholas Murray Butler at the commencement of Columbia University follows:
Dr. Nicholas Murray Buffer, president of Columbia University, warned yesterday against too great expansion of Federal power at the expense of the taxpayers.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The President placed his drought-relief program before Congressional leaders, and asked Congress for authority to give to Haiti property which marines will leave behind when they depart. He conferred with leaders in the automobile industry who are opposed to the Wagner bill, and with General Johnson on the threatened steel strike.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, June 5. -- Campfires were twinkling on Epsom Downs tonight as the advance guard of a million onlookers began gathering for the 151st running of the English Derby stakes tomorrow afternoon.
Cardinal Hayes urged 134 members of the graduating class of the College of Mount St. Vincent yesterday to meet the challenge of a troubled world with loyalty to Catholic ideals.

THOMAS MANN'S "Joseph and His Brothers" I (Knopf, $2.50), the first volume of a trilogy that will be completed with "The Young Joseph" and "Joseph in Egypt,' barely introduces us to Joseph. It should have been called "The Story of Jacob" if the author wanted it to stand by itself, for it is with Jacob that Dr. Mann spends most of his time in this lush, loosely arranged chronicle of patriarchal times.

The Bureau of Railway Economics reported yesterday that the railroads in making a further gain in earnings in April increased net operating income 66.7 per cent. This brought the increase in net for the first four months of the year to 168.3 per cent above that in the same period of 1933.

BERLIN, June 5. -- The upward movement on the stock market here increased its momentum and buoyancy today. Almost the whole active list made advances, many of which were substantial, Most buoyant were the Brown Coal shares, Eintracht improving its rise of yesterday with an additional 4 1/2 points, while Niederlausitz made the day's record with an advance of 8 points.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- Although they failed to agree on a candidate for chairman to succeed Everett Sanders, the members of the Republican National Committee today agreed to raise sufficient funds to wipe out a deficit of $206,000. Some personally pledged contributions while the others agreed to raise an assigned quota.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- President Roosevelt today laid his $525,000,000 drought relief program before Congressional representatives of the fourteen States most severely affected. The members expressed satisfaction with the plan and the indications were that the Presidents action had stilled earlier demands for appropriations ranging up to $1,000,000,000.

A group of 650 New York public and parochial school teachers gathered yesterday afternoon at Seward Park High School, Ludlow and Grand Streets, to mark the completion of a four months' course at the Police Academy. Two hundred and fifty received certificates signifying their completion of a course in safety education and 400 received certificates for their studies in problems of juvenile delinquency.

With the compulsory city residence bill for city employes apparently facing defeat, the Board of Aldermen adopted a resolution yesterday calling upon all appointing officials to observe the section of the Public Officers Law requiring all officials to be residents of the political subdivision in which they are appointed.

Guthrie McClintic announced yesterday that he has bought, and intends producing in New York early in September, an untitled play by Beatrice Kaufman, wife of George S. Kaufman, and Margaret Leech, wife of Ralph Pulitzer.

The strike of butchers and other packing house plant employes begun in Brooklyn on Monday spread to Manhattan yesterday, when 1,600 men quit work in the West Washington Market in response to a call by the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workers of America, the strike organization.

PENNINGTON, N.J., June 5. -- Dr. Francis Harvey Green, headmaster of Pennington School, awarded diplomas to a graduating class of twenty-nine this morning at the annual commencement exercises of the school in Shaw Memorial Chapel.

TRENTON, June 5. -- Assailing the New Jersey Code Adminstration as being unfair to consumers and favorable to large manufacturers, the Senate tonight adopted a resolution to appoint a special commission to investigate code practices in the State.

Mrs. Jane Mauldin Feigl, 55 years old, widow of Colonel Fred Feigl, former publisher and well known in military circles, was found dead yesterday in her room at the Hotel Somerset, 150 West Forty-seventh Street. Colonel Feigl died on Dec. 10, 1933.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP). -- April crude petroleum production in the United States was estimated today by the Bureau of Mines at 75,796,000 barrels, a daily average of 2,526,000 barrels.

An indictment growing out of the alleged manufacture and distribution of candies containing a small portion of an alcoholic substance in violation of the Pure Food and Drug Act was handed up to Judge Mortimer W. Byers in the United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday by the Federal grand jury.

The annual Founders Exhibition opened yesterday at the Grand Central Galleries. It contains paintings and sculpture by fifty artist members. These works of art, following a custom of long standing, will be distributed among the gallery's lay members in the Autumn.
Whitford Kane, recently seen on Broadway in "Yellow Jack," has signed a contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and left for the Hollywood studios. This is his first film experience.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- John Collier, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, denounced today as "an audacious attempt to seize Indian prop6rties" the opposition to the Wheeler-Howard bill. The measure is now pending in the House Indian Affairs Committee, where it has undergone drastic alteration since its introduction at the instance of Mr. Collier as a "Magna Charta for the American Indian."

NEWARK, N.J., June 5. -- One hundred and thirteen seniors will receive the degree of Graduate in Pharmacy at the forty-second annual commencement of the New Jersey College of Pharmacy of Rutgers University in the West Side High School here tomorrow night.

Restoration of the Maine Monument at the Columbus Circle entrance to Central Park has been begun by relief workers, it was announced yesterday by the Park Department. The memorial to the men who lost their lives when the battleship Maine was blown up, in Havana Harbor, on Feb. 15, 1898, was said to have been the object of "unusual vandalism."
ST. LOUIS, June 5 (AP). -- The sturdy right arm of Paul Dean today earned a sixth consecutive victory for its owner and gave the Cardinals a 6-to-3 decision over the Cubs.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Facts and figures to show that officials of the German Government had spent money for the dissemination of pro-German information in the United States were placed today before a special House committee.

DETROIT, June 5 (AP). -- The Detroit Tigers split a double-header today with Cleveland, and if Shortstop Knickerbocker of the Indians had not slammed a triple in the ninth inning to win the nightcap, Detroit would be leading the league tonight.
ROME, June 5. -- With the approach of June 15 an increasing amount of attention and study are being given to the problem of Italy's debt payment to the United States.

Few in Washington could have been surprised at the British note suspending payments on the war debts. Our Treasury could have got another $7,500,000 or so on account had not the Johnson bill, signed by the President, severely held such a "token" to be really a default.

Whatever you may think of Bobby Sanford's "Showboat Revue," it is a good idea to have a floating playhouse on the Hudson and to go there on a pleasant evening. The good ship Buccaneer is moored again in Tappan Zee, where the Flying Dutchman used to sail.

LONDON, June 5 (AP). -- The names of twenty-two American society women and debutantes who will be presented to King George and Queen Mary at the third and fourth royal courts next Tuesday and Wednesday by Mrs. Robert W. Bingham, wife of the United States Ambassador, were announced today.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 5. -- Governor James Rolph, who carried life insurance policies aggregating $1,000,084, died virtually penniless because he insisted that his debts be paid.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 5. -- The Mount Vernon Trust Company, rated as the largest bank between New York and Albany and between New York and Central New England, was opened this morning by order of Joseph A. Broderick, Superintendent of Banks, bringing financial relief to the institution's 22,000 depositors.

An exhibition of books and prints relating to aeronautics will open today in the main exhibition room of the New York Public Library. The exhibition attempts to trace the story of man's efforts to navigate the air from the first experiment of the Montgolfier brothers in 1783 to the closing years of the nineteenth century.
Conveyance of a loft building and a house in Union City featured the New Jersey activity reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- Steps to dethrone William S. Vare as Republican boss of Philadelphia were taken today at a caucus representing two-thirds of the membership i of the new Republican city committee.

PARIS, June 5. -- The Standard Oil Company's new refinery at Port Jerome, near Havre, was dedicated today in the presence of 500 representatives of Franco-American commerce. The refinery covers an immense rectangle 2,000 meters by 700 meters along the Seine and is equipped with the most modern installation.

LONDON, June 5. -- The stock market was firmer today, but still there was little business. The price of gold rose 10d to 138s an ounce, as a result of the depreciation of sterling, and brought renewed demand for gold mining stocks. British funds were quiet.

LONDON, June 5. -- Cheers from all parts of the House of Commons this afternoon greeted the announcement by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer. that the British Government had decided not to pay anything on the war debt to the United States on June 15.

Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, told 150 railway executives, bankers and security dealers assembled at the Bond Club luncheon in the Bankers Club yesterday that "the conservatives have not been conservative" in business and finance and, in respect to railroad finance, he urged a return to something like the restrained methods followed in New England forty or fifty years ago.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- On the witness stand here today Secretary Ickes charged that Lucius J.M. Malmin, former Federal judge of the Virgin Islands, and C.W. Larsen, former Assistant Corporation Counsel, had entered into a conspiracy to blackmail him and defame his character in an effort to obtain a high Federal post for Mr. Malmin.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- Ky Laffoon, 25-year-old Denver professional who has been playing as many as forty-five holes a day in preparation for the national open golf championship at the Merion Golf Club, gave the remainder of the field something to think about today when he scored a 67 for his second sub-par round in three days.

ST. JOHNS, Nfld., June 5. -- Fire raged through the little fishing settlement of Keels today, destroying twenty-two dwellings and other buildings and leaving more than 100 persons homeless before the flames were quenched by rain tonight.

A solemn pontifical mass was sung in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday for the Rev. Dr. Gabriel Oussani. In the chancel sat 125 priests and monsignori who had received instruction from him during the last thirty years at St. Joseph's Seminary, Dunwoodie, N.Y., and at Cathedral College, where he held the posts of Professor of Archaeology, Patrology and Early Church History.

The hearings on the copyright treaty before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations reveal a clear issue of principle against privilege. The Senate confronts this question: Shall the fundamental right of an author to the proceeds of his work -- a right specifically recognized in the Constitution -- give way to the desire of secondary commercial interests, chiefly distributors, to use such work without compensation to the producer?

In ten minutes yesterday a General Sessions jury returned a verdict of guilty of first-degree robbery against George Wilson and William Rogers in the holdup of an itinerant jeweler in a room in the Hotel Woodstock on Dec. 23, 1930.

In the settlement of the cotton textile dispute the main contention has been left open. According to General JOHNSON, the threatened strike was not directed primarily against the NRA order restricting machine hours 25 per cent during the Summer months. The necessity for this action was conceded by the labor representatives.

A.C. Needles, president of the Norfolk Western Railway, received all annual salary of $60,000 in 1933, compared with $75,000 reported on Dec. 1, 1929, and with $67,500 on March 1, 1932, according to a report filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. The company's salary list for 1933 follows:

The Dieppe Corporation, operator of the Central Park Casino, took steps yesterday to prevent Park Commissioner Robert Moses from breaking its ten-year lease. Mr. Moses had previously ordered the Dieppe Corporation to vacate the premises by midnight of June 15.

In his commencement day address yesterday President BUTLER of Columbia attempted to distinguish between the functions of law in this country and those of liberty. The American scheme of government, he argued, from the first left open an immense area of activities and public service to voluntary effort.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- James A. Farley will continue as Democratic National Chairman, at least until after the last September primary.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 5. -- President Roosevelt sent his personal greetings and wishes for success to the American Newspaper Guild, opening its first convention here today. The message, telegraphed to Heywood Broun of New York, president of the guild, said:

One subject on which President ROOSEVELT does not desire legislation at this session is waterways. Somewhat haphazardly and without debate, the Senate voted last February to request him to prepare "a comprehensive plan for the improvement and "development of the rivers of the "United States," designed especially to provide for "the maximum amount "of flood control, navigation, irriga- "tion and development of hydroelec- "tric power."

Eighteen crews will row in the three events of the thirty-sixth regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association at Poughkeepsie on June 18, according to the draw made yesterday at the office of Maxwell Stevenson, chairman of the board of stewards. Seven crews will start in the varsity, five in the junior varsity and six in the freshman race.

The last fifty years have seen more progress in medical science than had been made in all previous millenniums of human history, the graduating class of the New York Homeopathic Medical College and Flower Hospital were told last night at Town Hall by Dr. Harold Rypins, secretary of the Board of Medical Examiners of the University of the State of New York, Since 1890, he said, medicine has prolonged the average life 40 per cent.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 5. -- Senator Arthur R. Robinson was renominated by acclamation this afternoon by the Republican State Convention. The move to stop him collapsed when the opposition forces would not agree on a candidate.

The newly decorated roof garden of the Astor, one of the largest roof restaurants in the world, was opened last night for the Summer season with a large attendance. A special dinner dance took place in the Belvedere Restaurant and later a supper dance was held in the outdoor Terrace Cafe. The South Garden Lounge, adjacent to the roof garden, also had its inaugural.
The necessity of defending academic freedom and the freedom of the press was emphasized yesterday by speakers at the annual Columbia University luncheon in John Jay Hall.
I question the conclusions published in THE TIMES under the title "Religion Among Jews Found to Be Waning."
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The June grain crop report, scheduled for next Monday, has been advanced to Friday next, so that the information may be earlier available to relief officials.

The third code to be formulated by the Music Publishers Association of the United States was adopted at its twenty-first annual meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday after discussions which lasted most of the day. A price-fixing clause which, coupled with a misunderstanding with distributers, caused two previous codes to be thrown out by the government has been eliminated, and the corrected code will be resubmitted immediately.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP). -- In their seventh and eighth extra inning battles of the current season the Senators divided a double bill with the Athletics today, winning 4 to 3 in ten innings after losin 8 to ? over a similar route.

BERLIN, June 5 (AP). -- The defeat of Victor Ridder as president of the German-American Conference of Greater New York was acclaimed today by the National Socialist party's organ Korrespondenz as the "most significant event" among German in the United States since the World War.

With Bill Nicholas pitching shut-out ball, the Textile High School nine won the championship of the Manhattan - Bronx - Richmond division of the P.S.A.L. yesterday by defeating Theodore Roosevelt, 12 -- 0, on the Erasmus diamond.

MANHASSET, L.I., June 5. -- Mrs. Prentice Cromwell of New York and Mrs. Benjamin Brewster Jennings of Glen Head won the North-South high score and Mrs. George deforest Lord of Syosset and Mrs. Hiram E. Dewing of Locust Valley the East-West in the opening game of the benefit duplicate contract bridge tournament this afternoon at the country home of Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson.
Columbia University yesterday announced 108 athletic awards to members of various teams. Of these, 105 were for Spring sports and 3 for Winter sports.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 5 (AP). -- Syracuse won the last game of the Albany series, 10 to 5, today in the International League. The Chiefs scored four runs in each of the first and seventh innings. Bissonette hit a long home run over the right field wall for Albany in the third inning and Rosenfeld dropped a homer over the left field fence.

Cards listing the welfare agencies of the city's five boroughs to which persons in need of alms, food or shelter may be directed have been printed by the Department of Public Welfare and will be distributed to the public within the next few days, according to an announcement made yesterday by the Welfare Council of New York City.

The method of grading examination papers of candidates for master plumbers' licenses used by the city's Examining Board of Plumbers was criticized yesterday by Irving Ben Cooper, special counsel to Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard and by witnesses at a public hearing on the actions of the board.

Six new freight ships, capable of a speed of 18 1/2 knots, will be built by the Nippon Yusen Kaisha, pioneer ship line in the service between the Orient and New York, it was announced yesterday. The first of the fleet, the Nagara Maru, is scheduled to make her maiden Voyage late in September and the others will follow at intervals until the last ship is in operation in March, 1935.

MOSCOW, June 5. -- Another attack on the inefficiency of the railways, which is the greatest handicap to Soviet industry, was delivered today by Joseph Stalin and V.V. Quibesheff, head of the State Planning Commission, in a decree reorganizing the system of manufacturing replacement parts for rolling stock.

Gains were the rule on the commodity futures markets yesterday, reflecting the better tendency in outside markets, but coffee and copper were easier amid the general firmness. In the cash markets all the grains, sugar and cotton advanced, while zinc and tin declined.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- Embarrassment overwhelmed Casey Stengel's Dodgers today as they walked silently off the field in the slanting rays of the setting sun after losing both ends of a doubleheader to the Phillies, 11 to 10 and 5 to 4.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 5. -- Chamik, veteran bay gelding from the Warfield Farmm of E.P. Warfield of Port Chester, N.Y., which was ridden by Miss Becky Lanier, today won the first leg on the new Foxhunters Challenge Cup, presented by Mrs. Alvin Untermyer of Greenwich, Conn.
DES MOINES, June 5 (AP). -- A Progressive Republican and a Roosevelt Democrat will battle for the Iowa Governorship next Fall, returns from yesterday's primary election showed today.

The Brooklyn authorities received yesterday from a wholly unexpected source an offer of assistance in establishing whether Thomas P. Jensen, now in the Brooklyn city prison, is the same Thomas Jensen, or Johnson, who twenty years ago, is said to have murdered two men and a woman on a prospecting trip in Alaska.

GOSHEN, N.Y., June 5. -- Pool sellers and hand-bookmakers were kept busy at the historic track at the opening of the three-day trotting meeting of the Bay State Circuit today. A crowd of 5,000 was on hand.

For nearly two decades JEANS and EDDINGTON have been telling us that deep within the sun and the stars there are radioactive atoms compared with which radium and uranium are feeble performers. These hypothetical atoms are heavier than any we know. They radiate themselves away in an almost interminable process of self-annihilation brought on by collisions among themselves.

Your editorial "Silver and the Orient" is timely, especially since, in all the discussion of the new Silver Bill, nothing has been said of the results of Professor James H. Rogers's researches in China. It is also surprising to find one of Raymond Moley's intelligence -- remember he was even sent to the London Monetary Conference -- stating editorially in the April 28 issue of Today:

The ninetieth anniversary of the founding in London, England, of the Young Men's Christian Association will be observed today at Y.M.C.A. meetings throughout the United States. "The Outlook for Youth in the Coming Decade and How the Y Can Best Function in Completing a Century of Service to Young Men and Boys" will be the general topic of speakers at the anniversary meetings.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- The philosophy of the New Deal was criticized today by Malcolm P. McNair, director of research of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, in a talk before members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in session here.

LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, June 5 (Via Mackay Radio). -- This polar community today entered the fourteenth day of what might be called the hottest Winter heat wave in the memory of the oldest inhabitants. As 8 o'clock this morning the temperature soared to 25 degrees above zero, equaling the record maximum set less than two weeks ago.

Thomas Mark, 39 years old, of 288 Eckford Street, Brooklyn, has placed grand larceny on a tonnage basis, according to police of the Maspeth precinct in Queens. He was arraigned before Magistrate Marvin in Ridgewood Court yesterday, charged with stealing a concrete-mixing machine.

CHICAGO, June 5 (AP). -- The White Sox and the Browns split the first doubleheader of the year at Comiskey Park today. The White Sox won the first game 8 to 2 and the second went to St. Louis 10 to 5.
PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- Forty-six students of the University of Pennsylvania were fined $10 and costs of $3.50 each today for disturbing West Philadelphia's peace and order a few hours earlier.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- For the first time since a drastic "gag" rule was adopted in the House on Friday to speed legislation, the Democratic majority split today, with a result that the leadership was defeated on a measure designed to provide 102,950 temporary jobs near election time in November.

The mark succeeded sterling yesterday as the weak feature of the foreign exchange market. On rumors of impending devaluation it fell to 37.60 cents, the lowest price since Feb. 5, and closed at 37.65 cents, off 1.23 cents.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- A plea that the church support a positive program for removing potential causes of war was made today by the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, in an address at the final session of the Annual Conference of Liberal Evangelicals.

Mayor LaGuardia had dinner last night with the members of the City Charter Revision Commission, of which former Governor Alfred E. Smith is chairman, pledged the cooperation of his administration and then left the commission to complete the task of organization.

Dr. Charles Fama, who was appointed last month by the Board of Estimate as an examining physician for the New York City Employes Retirement System, was directed by resolution of the Board of Aldermen yesterday to appear before its special investigating committee to answer charges of religious intolerance.

After counsel for ten Communists, arrested a week ago last Saturday in the rioting in front of the Welfare Department's relief office in Lafayette Street, had refused yesterday to offer defense evidence, Magistrate August Dreyer, sitting in the Homicide Court, held the defendants for the grand jury on felony charges.

Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College told the graduates and their parents and friends at the clase day exercises yesterday afternoon that "this new day of the 'New Deal' that we are seeing in this country is, of course, just dawning."

The United States Supreme Court will hear an appeal in behalf of mortgage certificate holders from the decision of the State Court of Appeals upholding the validity of the Schackno Act for the reorganization of guaranteed mortgage properties.

The late Mrs. Florence A. Pratt, daughter of Isaac Singer, sewing machine inventor, developed "mental delusions" in 1918 or earlier and "was not possessed of the testamentary capacity required by our laws," Harold H. Corbin, an attorney, declared yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- Buying of wheat on the Board of Trade was led today by brokerage houses with Eastern connections and by the public during a large part of the last few hours of trading. It was found necessary to bid prices up several cents to get wheat, and the close was around the day's best prices, with net gains 3 7/8 to 4 1/8 cents a bushel.
The ninety ships of the fleet were still the city's biggest attraction yesterday as 60,000 persons crowded the decks of the men-of-war, anchored in the Hudson or moored to piers in four boroughs.

Telegrams expressing "the indignation of the Women's Christian Temperance Union" over conditions alleged to result from the use of intoxicating liquor by the sailors in New York have been sent to President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman and Mayor LaGuardia by Mrs. Caroline Relyea, president of the New York County W.C.T.U.

Sturdy little Finland continues to impress spectators as a nation that goes her own way, independent of the fashions. She punctually meets her war debt installments to the United States at a time when nobody else does.

BOSTON, June 5. -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology graduated the largest class in its history at its annual commencement exercises this morning in the presence of an audience which filled Symphony Hall.

BERLIN, June 5. -- The German Catholic Bishops met today in Fulga for a conference which may be decisive for relations between the Hiltier government and the Roman Catholic Church. The government's claim to the control of every aspect of the coming generation's education, with the exception of the strictly religious, has brought it in sharp conflict with the Catholics' effort to maintain contact with every activity of Catholic youth.

Value of Dollar on Exchange Market The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

John W. Binks, master of the British-owned White Star liner Olympic, who has skippered vessels at sea for more than twenty years, arrived in port last night, in command of his 47,000-ton steamship, to learn that the Government of the United States had accused him and his officers of incompetence and unseamanlike conduct.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,453,400 barrels, against 2,492,500 in the preceding week, a decline of 39,100, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Decreases of 34,100 barrels in Oklahoma and 19,200 in California were among the most important changes for the week.

The National Recovery Act and President Roosevelt were praised at the annual meeting yesterday of the National Piano Manufacturers Association of America at their headquarters, 45 West Forty-fifth Street. In his annual report to the gathering, Lucien Wulsin, president of the organization and head of the Baldwin Piano Company, declared that the piano manufacturers' code had bettered the piano trade considerably.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 5. -- Seven players were named by Mrs. Jeannette Chappell Hitchcock and her committee today to represent the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association in the Sears Cup matches at Baltimore on Friday and Saturday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 (AP). -- While a host of notables, including former President Herbert Hoover, stood silently by, the pathetic voice of a little child said a tearful farewell to his friend, Governor James Rolph Jr., at the Governor's funeral here today.

GLEN COVE, L.I., N.Y., June 5. -- With a round of almost perfect golf, Miss Helen Hicks, defending champion, scored a 9 and 7 triumph over Mrs. George Hackney of Nassau as match play started today in the women's Long Island golf championship.

A prize of $300 and a trip to France, awarded by the Societe des Professeurs en Amerique, on the basis of a competitive examination open to all graduates of colleges, has been awarded Elise Silverman of the Hunter College class of 32, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Four spokesmen for the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce urged the President at a White House conference today not to "impair" the general improvement of labor relations by "creation of new controversies out of new legislative interpretations at this time."

Herbert Agar, author of "The People's Choice," which won the Pulitzer Prize of $2,000 for 1934, arrived last night from London on the White Star liner Olympic accompanied by his wife, Eleanor Carroll Chilton, a novelist, who has just completed her third book, "Follow the Furies," to be published here in the Fall.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 5. -- Mrs. H. Van Rensselaer Kennedy was hostess this afternoon at a garden tea at Three Oaks, her country home near this village, for the benefit of the Nassau County Girl Scout Council.

After the extremely slow trading of the last few weeks, yesterday's business on the Stock Exchange, although it reached only the moderate proportions of 740,000 shares, seemed to Wall Street to set a lively pace. The turnover was more than twice as large as on the day before.

Influenced by the strength in other markets and continued rains in Eastern districts, where moisture is not wanted, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward sharply $1.50 a bale yesterday and closed around the top at gains of 27 to 30 points.

ALBANY, June 5. -- A State-wide rise of a cent a quart on milk was ordered by the Milk Advisory Committee today as a result of the drought. At a meeting with Charles H. Baldwin of the Department of Agriculture and Markets, it was pointed out that, because pastures are sun-baked, producers will be forced to feed grain to their cattle.

The report of the United States Electric Power Corporation and subsidiaries for 1933 says that on Dec. 31 the principal amount of the parent company's bank loans had been reduced to $12,177,804, plus unpaid interest accrued of $623,754, comparing with $12,500,000 on March 1, 1933, and with $13,500,000 on Dec. 31, 1932.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP). -- Start of an extensive groundwork program by the aeronautics branch of the Department of Commerce, designed to render the country's air transport system "safer and more efficient than ever before," was outlined tonight by Postmaster General Farley.

The Lawyers Mortgage Company finance committee induced the executive committee to continue paying dividends in 1932 after it had voted to stop them, according to testimony yesterday before George W. Alger, Moreland Act Commissioner.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- Lightweight hogs were in large supply today and the market was steady to 25 cents a hundredweight lower. Other hogs were sold at steady prices, the extreme top at $3.65, being the same as on A~[onday. The average price was at $3.20, a drop of 5 cents.

LONDON, June 5. -- The type of boom which Endeavour will carry in the America's Cup races is now being carefully considered in view of the fact that both she and Velsheda recently broke the flat flexible booms with which they were fitted.

NEWARK, N.J., June 5. -- The Bears ended a short home stand today by defeating Baltimore, 6 to 4. It was Newark's third victory in four games with the Orioles and the fifth in eight contests during the week on home soil.

Ninety-nine students of the Savage School for Physical Education will receive diplomas tonight at the annual commencement of the school, at the Town Hall, 113 West Forty-third Street. The school is at 308 West Fifty-ninth Street.

A jury before Supreme Court Justice Miller decided yesterday that Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence L. Gillespie must pay $1,500 to Dr. Russell H. Patterson of 135 East Sixty-fifth Street in a suit for $2,500 for medical services. The services included blood transfusions and glucose transfusions given the defendants' daughter, Doris, following a mastoid operation in May, 1931.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 5. -- A new corporation was created by order of Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley this afternoon to manage the more than $85,000,000 of mortgages of the three Westchester title companies now under rehabilitation by the State Superintendent of Insurance.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The processing tax on direct-consumption sugar from beets and cane was set today at half a cent a pound of raw value by Rexford G. Tugwell, Acting Secretary of Agriculture. The tax is to take effect Friday.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey is earning a net profit of approximately $3,500,000 monthly and has been doing so since about the middle of 1933, W.S. Farish, chairman, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting of the company.

Shaking off the lethargy which on two or three occasions recently has reduced the volume of trading to the lowest levels in ten years, the share market gave a much more animated performance yesterday. Not only was there an increase in business, but there was quite a spirited advance in prices.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 5. -- Miss Catherine Dix, former secretary to Flo Ziegfeld and Billie Burke, testified here today in the discovery proceeding authorized by the Surrogate's Court to determine the value of the name "Ziegfeld Follies." The proceeding was brought by County Treasurer William S. Coffey, as administrator of the estate of Flo Ziegfeld.

Thirty-three members of the class of 1890, Columbia Law School, received belated degrees of Bachelor of Law from Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, at the commencement exercises yesterday.

The award of thirteen $300 scholarships for college undergraduate study abroad was announced yesterday by the Institute of International Education. The winners, who took part in a competition of about thirty-five students, will spend their junior year in France with the group organized by the committee on foreign study of the University of France.

Strength in all classes of domestic issues, including United States Government securities, and weakness in foreign issues characterized the trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. There was a substantial improvement in the volume of trading.

LONDON, June 5. -- Editorial approval of the government's refusal to pay the war debt to the United States as expressed in tomorrow's London newspapers will be as unanimous as that demonstrated today in the House of Commons.

Due to the holiday, the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was the smallest for any week this year. The total was also well below the number registered in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., June 5 (AP). -- Current banking problems will be discussed when bankers throughout New York State gather here June 10, 11 and 12 for the annual convention of the State Bankers Association.

MADISON, N.J., June 5. -- Drew University held its sixty-seventh commencement exercises here today. For the first time the university graduated a student summa cum laude. The student is Benjamin Goldenberg of Morristown, who finished the four-year course, majoring in English literature, in three years.

GENEVA, June 5. -- The cat, monkey and parrot imbroglio into which the World Disarmament Conference has degenerated in the last two days continued throughout this afternoon with a heat and fervor rivaling if not surpassing that of yesterday.

The Forty-niners, a group of players from the Yale University Theatre, will open their Summer season in the new theatre, transformed from a barn, on the Chase Farm at Whitefield, N.H., on July 13. The schedule is:

In connection with the plans of the Guaranty Trust Company to discontinue the securities business of the Guaranty Company, its affiliate, it was reported yesterday that Edward B. Smith Co. would take over the major part of the Guaranty Company's business and that Joseph R. Swann, president of the Guaranty Company, would become a partner in the firm.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Postmaster General Farley, who also dispenses Democratic patronage, held a press conference today to celebrate the opening of his offices in the new Postoffice Department Building.

PARIS, June 5. -- The Bourse, which was bad yesterday, became worse today. The downward trend was accelerated from the opening to the close and the end of the session found stocks and bonds at the lowest levels of the day almost without exception.

Clifford Sutter and Gregory Mangin, fourth and fifth in the nation's ranking, passed out of the Brooklyn tennis championship at the Terrace Club of Flatbush yesterday in two of the biggest upsets in the seventeen years of the tourney.

UNDERWOOD, Ind., June 5 (AP). -- Kidnapping of an 18-year-old farm boy today followed the slaying by three youthful bandits of a deputy sheriff and the wounding of a policeman in a wild flight that began last night. A posse of some 200 men aided by bloodhounds took up the trail.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- A "showdown" in the Senate on cash payment of the veterans' bonus, an issue which leaders had hoped to avoid by early adjournment, appeared inevitable today after the Finance Committee had agreed to report action on the Patman bill, long since passed by the House.
TORONTO, June 5 (AP). -- Al Hollingsworth registered his seventh successive victory today as Toronto defeated Montreal, 5 to 2, in the final game of their series.

PARIS, June 5. -- Discussion of the war debt situation was postponed today by the Cabinet "because of the continued absence of Foreign Minister Barthou" and also because the action of the British Government in suspending payments to the United States has interjected a new and very Important argument into the debate.

Plaintiffs bid in the eleven properties offered at foreclosure auction sales in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday. Seven parcels in the former borough and four in the latter went under the hammer, as follows:
The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange voted yesterday several amendments in by-laws and rules principally for changing the commission rules in order to reduce the cost to customers of "straddles."
Multi-family houses furnished the bulk of trading as reported by Manhattan realty brokers yesterday. Two apartment buildings were listed in new ownership.

International interest in shellac, a commodity which hitherto has been discussed seldom in speculative circles, again has induced the board of governors of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., to consider the advisability of establishing a futures market in the material here.

A new issue of $3,000,000 Commonwealth of Massachusetts 2 per cent Emergency Public Works Loan bonds dated June 1 and due on June 1, 1935 to 1944 inclusive, will be offered today by a banking group headed by the Chase National Bank of New York at prices to yield 0.375 per cent to 3.10 per cent, according to maturity.

The directors of the Kennecott Copper Corporation declared yesterday a distribution of 15 cents a share on the common stock. This will be the first dividend to be paid by that company since Jan. 2, 1932, when 12 1/2 cents a share was disbursed.
What the market collapse of 1929 did to the wealth that Joseph W. Harriman had accumulated in fifty years of banking was examined yesterday at his trial in Federal court.

WESTFIELD, N.J., June 5. -- Miss Charlotte Glutting of the Rock Spring Country Club had a commanding lead of thirteen strokes at the end of the second round of the 54-hole medal play championship of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Shackamaxon Country Club today.

Under the elm trees that skirt the open space at the north end of the Mall in Central Park, thousands danced last night, while stars twinkled overhead. There was no charge for anything, and the band played everything that the dancers' hearts desired, for the asking.

BERLIN, June 5. -- The German reaction to the disarmament conference, long composed of mixed feelings, seems now to be dominated by an "I-told-you-so" sentiment. The final collapse of the conference is held to be imminent.

A charge of juvenile delinquency was made yesterday by the Brooklyn police against George Munroe, 15 years old, of 17 Rock Street, Brooklyn, who, it is charged, was the schoolmate who fought on Monday with Meyer Geller, 13, of 164 McKibbin Street, causing the Geller boy to die later of a fractured skull.
LONDON, June 5. -- Former Chancellor Heinrich Bruening, who has been in England on a private visit for the past ten days, intends to return to Germany this week, it was learned today.

HAVANA, June 5. -- The suspension of constitutional guarantees of the republic will be continued for ninety days, it was announced this afternoon by Dr. Carlos de la Rionda, Secretary of Agriculture and Acting Secretary of the Interior.
